# AdaptiveCrawler - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

AdaptiveCrawler
===============

The `AdaptiveCrawler` class implements intelligent web crawling that automatically determines when sufficient information has been gathered to answer a query. It uses a three-layer scoring system to evaluate coverage, consistency, and saturation.

Constructor
-----------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-0-1) AdaptiveCrawler( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-0-2)     crawler: AsyncWebCrawler, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-0-3)     config: Optional[AdaptiveConfig] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-0-4) )`

### Parameters

*   **crawler** (`AsyncWebCrawler`): The underlying web crawler instance to use for fetching pages
*   **config** (`Optional[AdaptiveConfig]`): Configuration settings for adaptive crawling behavior. If not provided, uses default settings.

Primary Method
--------------

### digest()

The main method that performs adaptive crawling starting from a URL with a specific query.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-1-1) async def digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-1-2)     start_url: str, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-1-3)     query: str, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-1-4)     resume_from: Optional[Union[str, Path]] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-1-5) ) -> CrawlState`

#### Parameters

*   **start\_url** (`str`): The starting URL for crawling
*   **query** (`str`): The search query that guides the crawling process
*   **resume\_from** (`Optional[Union[str, Path]]`): Path to a saved state file to resume from

#### Returns

*   **CrawlState**: The final crawl state containing all crawled URLs, knowledge base, and metrics

#### Example

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-2-1) async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-2-2)     adaptive = AdaptiveCrawler(crawler) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-2-3)     state = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-2-4)         start_url="https://docs.python.org", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-2-5)         query="async context managers" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-2-6)     )`

Properties
----------

### confidence

Current confidence score (0-1) indicating information sufficiency.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-3-1) @property [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-3-2) def confidence(self) -> float`

### coverage\_stats

Dictionary containing detailed coverage statistics.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-4-1) @property   [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-4-2) def coverage_stats(self) -> Dict[str, float]`

Returns: - **coverage**: Query term coverage score - **consistency**: Information consistency score  
\- **saturation**: Content saturation score - **confidence**: Overall confidence score

### is\_sufficient

Boolean indicating whether sufficient information has been gathered.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-5-1) @property [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-5-2) def is_sufficient(self) -> bool`

### state

Access to the current crawl state.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-6-1) @property [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-6-2) def state(self) -> CrawlState`

Methods
-------

### get\_relevant\_content()

Retrieve the most relevant content from the knowledge base.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-7-1) def get_relevant_content( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-7-2)     self, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-7-3)     top_k: int = 5 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-7-4) ) -> List[Dict[str, Any]]`

#### Parameters

*   **top\_k** (`int`): Number of top relevant documents to return (default: 5)

#### Returns

List of dictionaries containing: - **url**: The URL of the page - **content**: The page content - **score**: Relevance score - **metadata**: Additional page metadata

### print\_stats()

Display crawl statistics in formatted output.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-8-1) def print_stats( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-8-2)     self, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-8-3)     detailed: bool = False [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-8-4) ) -> None`

#### Parameters

*   **detailed** (`bool`): If True, shows detailed metrics with colors. If False, shows summary table.

### export\_knowledge\_base()

Export the collected knowledge base to a JSONL file.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-9-1) def export_knowledge_base( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-9-2)     self, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-9-3)     path: Union[str, Path] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-9-4) ) -> None`

#### Parameters

*   **path** (`Union[str, Path]`): Output file path for JSONL export

#### Example

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-10-1) adaptive.export_knowledge_base("my_knowledge.jsonl")`

### import\_knowledge\_base()

Import a previously exported knowledge base.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-11-1) def import_knowledge_base( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-11-2)     self, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-11-3)     path: Union[str, Path] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-11-4) ) -> None`

#### Parameters

*   **path** (`Union[str, Path]`): Path to JSONL file to import

Configuration
-------------

The `AdaptiveConfig` class controls the behavior of adaptive crawling:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-12-1) @dataclass [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-12-2) class AdaptiveConfig: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-12-3)     confidence_threshold: float = 0.8      # Stop when confidence reaches this [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-12-4)     max_pages: int = 50                    # Maximum pages to crawl [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-12-5)     top_k_links: int = 5                   # Links to follow per page [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-12-6)     min_gain_threshold: float = 0.1        # Minimum expected gain to continue [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-12-7)     save_state: bool = False               # Auto-save crawl state [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-12-8)     state_path: Optional[str] = None       # Path for state persistence`

### Example with Custom Config

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-13-1) config = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-13-2)     confidence_threshold=0.7, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-13-3)     max_pages=20, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-13-4)     top_k_links=3 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-13-5) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-13-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-13-7) adaptive = AdaptiveCrawler(crawler, config=config)`

Complete Example
----------------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-2) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, AdaptiveCrawler, AdaptiveConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-4) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-5)     # Configure adaptive crawling [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-6)     config = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-7)         confidence_threshold=0.75, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-8)         max_pages=15, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-9)         save_state=True, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-10)         state_path="my_crawl.json" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-11)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-12) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-13)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-14)         adaptive = AdaptiveCrawler(crawler, config) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-15) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-16)         # Start crawling [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-17)         state = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-18)             start_url="https://example.com/docs", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-19)             query="authentication oauth2 jwt" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-20)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-21) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-22)         # Check results [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-23)         print(f"Confidence achieved: {adaptive.confidence:.0%}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-24)         adaptive.print_stats() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-25) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-26)         # Get most relevant pages [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-27)         for page in adaptive.get_relevant_content(top_k=3): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-28)             print(f"- {page['url']} (score: {page['score']:.2f})") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-29) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-30)         # Export for later use [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-31)         adaptive.export_knowledge_base("auth_knowledge.jsonl") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-32) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-33) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/adaptive-crawler/#__codelineno-14-34)     asyncio.run(main())`

# Strategies - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Extraction & Chunking Strategies API
====================================

This documentation covers the API reference for extraction and chunking strategies in Crawl4AI.

Extraction Strategies
---------------------

All extraction strategies inherit from the base `ExtractionStrategy` class and implement two key methods: - `extract(url: str, html: str) -> List[Dict[str, Any]]` - `run(url: str, sections: List[str]) -> List[Dict[str, Any]]`

### LLMExtractionStrategy

Used for extracting structured data using Language Models.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-1) LLMExtractionStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-2)     # Required Parameters [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-3)     provider: str = DEFAULT_PROVIDER,     # LLM provider (e.g., "ollama/llama2") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-4)     api_token: Optional[str] = None,      # API token [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-6)     # Extraction Configuration [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-7)     instruction: str = None,              # Custom extraction instruction [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-8)     schema: Dict = None,                  # Pydantic model schema for structured data [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-9)     extraction_type: str = "block",       # "block" or "schema" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-11)     # Chunking Parameters [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-12)     chunk_token_threshold: int = 4000,    # Maximum tokens per chunk [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-13)     overlap_rate: float = 0.1,           # Overlap between chunks [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-14)     word_token_rate: float = 0.75,       # Word to token conversion rate [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-15)     apply_chunking: bool = True,         # Enable/disable chunking [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-16) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-17)     # API Configuration [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-18)     base_url: str = None,                # Base URL for API [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-19)     extra_args: Dict = {},               # Additional provider arguments [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-20)     verbose: bool = False                # Enable verbose logging [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-0-21) )`

### CosineStrategy

Used for content similarity-based extraction and clustering.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-1) CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-2)     # Content Filtering [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-3)     semantic_filter: str = None,        # Topic/keyword filter [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-4)     word_count_threshold: int = 10,     # Minimum words per cluster [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-5)     sim_threshold: float = 0.3,         # Similarity threshold [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-7)     # Clustering Parameters [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-8)     max_dist: float = 0.2,             # Maximum cluster distance [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-9)     linkage_method: str = 'ward',       # Clustering method [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-10)     top_k: int = 3,                    # Top clusters to return [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-11) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-12)     # Model Configuration [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-13)     model_name: str = 'sentence-transformers/all-MiniLM-L6-v2',  # Embedding model [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-14) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-15)     verbose: bool = False              # Enable verbose logging [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-2-16) )`

Chunking Strategies
-------------------

All chunking strategies inherit from `ChunkingStrategy` and implement the `chunk(text: str) -> list` method.

### RegexChunking

Splits text based on regex patterns.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-4-1) RegexChunking( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-4-2)     patterns: List[str] = None  # Regex patterns for splitting [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-4-3)                                # Default: [r'\n\n'] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-4-4) )`

### SlidingWindowChunking

Creates overlapping chunks with a sliding window approach.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-5-1) SlidingWindowChunking( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-5-2)     window_size: int = 100,    # Window size in words [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-5-3)     step: int = 50             # Step size between windows [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-5-4) )`

### OverlappingWindowChunking

Creates chunks with specified overlap.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-6-1) OverlappingWindowChunking( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-6-2)     window_size: int = 1000,   # Chunk size in words [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-6-3)     overlap: int = 100         # Overlap size in words [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-6-4) )`

Usage Examples
--------------

### LLM Extraction

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-1) from pydantic import BaseModel [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-2) from crawl4ai import LLMExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-3) from crawl4ai import LLMConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-5) # Define schema [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-6) class Article(BaseModel): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-7)     title: str [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-8)     content: str [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-9)     author: str [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-11) # Create strategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-12) strategy = LLMExtractionStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-13)     llm_config = LLMConfig(provider="ollama/llama2"), [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-14)     schema=Article.schema(), [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-15)     instruction="Extract article details" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-16) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-17) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-18) # Use with crawler [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-19) result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-20)     url="https://example.com/article", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-21)     extraction_strategy=strategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-22) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-23) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-24) # Access extracted data [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-7-25) data = json.loads(result.extracted_content)`

### Regex Extraction

Best Practices
--------------

1.  **Choose the Right Strategy**
2.  Use `RegexExtractionStrategy` for common data types like emails, phones, URLs, dates
3.  Use `JsonCssExtractionStrategy` for well-structured HTML with consistent patterns
4.  Use `LLMExtractionStrategy` for complex, unstructured content requiring reasoning
5.  Use `CosineStrategy` for content similarity and clustering
    
6.  **Strategy Selection Guide**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-1) Is the target data a common type (email/phone/date/URL)?  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-2) → RegexExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-4) Does the page have consistent HTML structure? [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-5) → JsonCssExtractionStrategy or JsonXPathExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-7) Is the data semantically complex or unstructured? [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-8) → LLMExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-9) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-10) Need to find content similar to a specific topic? [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-11-11) → CosineStrategy`
    
7.  **Optimize Chunking**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-12-1) # For long documents [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-12-2) strategy = LLMExtractionStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-12-3)     chunk_token_threshold=2000,  # Smaller chunks [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-12-4)     overlap_rate=0.1           # 10% overlap [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-12-5) )`
    
8.  **Combine Strategies for Best Performance**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-1) # First pass: Extract structure with CSS [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-2) css_strategy = JsonCssExtractionStrategy(product_schema) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-3) css_result = await crawler.arun(url, config=CrawlerRunConfig(extraction_strategy=css_strategy)) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-4) product_data = json.loads(css_result.extracted_content) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-6) # Second pass: Extract specific fields with regex [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-7) descriptions = [product["description"] for product in product_data] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-8) regex_strategy = RegexExtractionStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-9)     pattern=RegexExtractionStrategy.Email | RegexExtractionStrategy.PhoneUS, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-10)     custom={"dimension": r"\d+x\d+x\d+ (?:cm|in)"} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-11) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-12) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-13) # Process descriptions with regex [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-14) for text in descriptions: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-13-15)     matches = regex_strategy.extract("", text)  # Direct extraction`
    
9.  **Handle Errors**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-14-1) try: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-14-2)     result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-14-3)         url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-14-4)         extraction_strategy=strategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-14-5)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-14-6)     if result.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-14-7)         content = json.loads(result.extracted_content) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-14-8) except Exception as e: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-14-9)     print(f"Extraction failed: {e}")`
    
10.  **Monitor Performance**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-15-1) strategy = CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-15-2)     verbose=True,  # Enable logging [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-15-3)     word_count_threshold=20,  # Filter short content [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-15-4)     top_k=5  # Limit results [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-15-5) )`
    
11.  **Cache Generated Patterns**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-1) # For RegexExtractionStrategy pattern generation [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-2) import json [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-3) from pathlib import Path [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-5) cache_dir = Path("./pattern_cache") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-6) cache_dir.mkdir(exist_ok=True) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-7) pattern_file = cache_dir / "product_pattern.json" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-9) if pattern_file.exists(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-10)     with open(pattern_file) as f: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-11)         pattern = json.load(f) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-12) else: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-13)     # Generate once with LLM [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/strategies/#__codelineno-16-14)     pattern = RegexExtractionStrategy.generate_pattern(...) # CrawlResult - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

`CrawlResult` Reference
=======================

The **`CrawlResult`** class encapsulates everything returned after a single crawl operation. It provides the **raw or processed content**, details on links and media, plus optional metadata (like screenshots, PDFs, or extracted JSON).

**Location**: `crawl4ai/crawler/models.py` (for reference)

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-1) class CrawlResult(BaseModel): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-2)     url: str [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-3)     html: str [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-4)     success: bool [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-5)     cleaned_html: Optional[str] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-6)     fit_html: Optional[str] = None  # Preprocessed HTML optimized for extraction [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-7)     media: Dict[str, List[Dict]] = {} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-8)     links: Dict[str, List[Dict]] = {} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-9)     downloaded_files: Optional[List[str]] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-10)     screenshot: Optional[str] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-11)     pdf : Optional[bytes] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-12)     mhtml: Optional[str] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-13)     markdown: Optional[Union[str, MarkdownGenerationResult]] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-14)     extracted_content: Optional[str] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-15)     metadata: Optional[dict] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-16)     error_message: Optional[str] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-17)     session_id: Optional[str] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-18)     response_headers: Optional[dict] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-19)     status_code: Optional[int] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-20)     ssl_certificate: Optional[SSLCertificate] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-21)     dispatch_result: Optional[DispatchResult] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-0-22)     ...`

Below is a **field-by-field** explanation and possible usage patterns.

* * *

1\. Basic Crawl Info
--------------------

### 1.1 **`url`** _(str)_

**What**: The final crawled URL (after any redirects).  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-1-1) print(result.url)  # e.g., "https://example.com/"`

### 1.2 **`success`** _(bool)_

**What**: `True` if the crawl pipeline ended without major errors; `False` otherwise.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-2-1) if not result.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-2-2)     print(f"Crawl failed: {result.error_message}")`

### 1.3 **`status_code`** _(Optional\[int\])_

**What**: The page's HTTP status code (e.g., 200, 404).  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-3-1) if result.status_code == 404: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-3-2)     print("Page not found!")`

### 1.4 **`error_message`** _(Optional\[str\])_

**What**: If `success=False`, a textual description of the failure.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-4-1) if not result.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-4-2)     print("Error:", result.error_message)`

### 1.5 **`session_id`** _(Optional\[str\])_

**What**: The ID used for reusing a browser context across multiple calls.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-5-1) # If you used session_id="login_session" in CrawlerRunConfig, see it here: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-5-2) print("Session:", result.session_id)`

### 1.6 **`response_headers`** _(Optional\[dict\])_

**What**: Final HTTP response headers.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-6-1) if result.response_headers: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-6-2)     print("Server:", result.response_headers.get("Server", "Unknown"))`

### 1.7 **`ssl_certificate`** _(Optional\[SSLCertificate\])_

**What**: If `fetch_ssl_certificate=True` in your CrawlerRunConfig, **`result.ssl_certificate`** contains a [**`SSLCertificate`**](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/ssl-certificate/)
 object describing the site's certificate. You can export the cert in multiple formats (PEM/DER/JSON) or access its properties like `issuer`, `subject`, `valid_from`, `valid_until`, etc. **Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-7-1) if result.ssl_certificate: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-7-2)     print("Issuer:", result.ssl_certificate.issuer)`

* * *

2\. Raw / Cleaned Content
-------------------------

### 2.1 **`html`** _(str)_

**What**: The **original** unmodified HTML from the final page load.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-8-1) # Possibly large [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-8-2) print(len(result.html))`

### 2.2 **`cleaned_html`** _(Optional\[str\])_

**What**: A sanitized HTML version—scripts, styles, or excluded tags are removed based on your `CrawlerRunConfig`.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-9-1) print(result.cleaned_html[:500])  # Show a snippet`

* * *

3\. Markdown Fields
-------------------

### 3.1 The Markdown Generation Approach

Crawl4AI can convert HTML→Markdown, optionally including:

*   **Raw** markdown
*   **Links as citations** (with a references section)
*   **Fit** markdown if a **content filter** is used (like Pruning or BM25)

**`MarkdownGenerationResult`** includes: - **`raw_markdown`** _(str)_: The full HTML→Markdown conversion.  
\- **`markdown_with_citations`** _(str)_: Same markdown, but with link references as academic-style citations.  
\- **`references_markdown`** _(str)_: The reference list or footnotes at the end.  
\- **`fit_markdown`** _(Optional\[str\])_: If content filtering (Pruning/BM25) was applied, the filtered "fit" text.  
\- **`fit_html`** _(Optional\[str\])_: The HTML that led to `fit_markdown`.

**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-10-1) if result.markdown: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-10-2)     md_res = result.markdown [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-10-3)     print("Raw MD:", md_res.raw_markdown[:300]) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-10-4)     print("Citations MD:", md_res.markdown_with_citations[:300]) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-10-5)     print("References:", md_res.references_markdown) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-10-6)     if md_res.fit_markdown: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-10-7)         print("Pruned text:", md_res.fit_markdown[:300])`

### 3.2 **`markdown`** _(Optional\[Union\[str, MarkdownGenerationResult\]\])_

**What**: Holds the `MarkdownGenerationResult`.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-11-1) print(result.markdown.raw_markdown[:200]) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-11-2) print(result.markdown.fit_markdown) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-11-3) print(result.markdown.fit_html)`

**Important**: "Fit" content (in `fit_markdown`/`fit_html`) exists in result.markdown, only if you used a **filter** (like **PruningContentFilter** or **BM25ContentFilter**) within a `MarkdownGenerationStrategy`.

* * *

4\. Media & Links
-----------------

### 4.1 **`media`** _(Dict\[str, List\[Dict\]\])_

**What**: Contains info about discovered images, videos, or audio. Typically keys: `"images"`, `"videos"`, `"audios"`.  
**Common Fields** in each item:

*   `src` _(str)_: Media URL
*   `alt` or `title` _(str)_: Descriptive text
*   `score` _(float)_: Relevance score if the crawler's heuristic found it "important"
*   `desc` or `description` _(Optional\[str\])_: Additional context extracted from surrounding text

**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-12-1) images = result.media.get("images", []) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-12-2) for img in images: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-12-3)     if img.get("score", 0) > 5: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-12-4)         print("High-value image:", img["src"])`

### 4.2 **`links`** _(Dict\[str, List\[Dict\]\])_

**What**: Holds internal and external link data. Usually two keys: `"internal"` and `"external"`.  
**Common Fields**:

*   `href` _(str)_: The link target
*   `text` _(str)_: Link text
*   `title` _(str)_: Title attribute
*   `context` _(str)_: Surrounding text snippet
*   `domain` _(str)_: If external, the domain

**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-13-1) for link in result.links["internal"]: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-13-2)     print(f"Internal link to {link['href']} with text {link['text']}")`

* * *

5\. Additional Fields
---------------------

### 5.1 **`extracted_content`** _(Optional\[str\])_

**What**: If you used **`extraction_strategy`** (CSS, LLM, etc.), the structured output (JSON).  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-14-1) if result.extracted_content: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-14-2)     data = json.loads(result.extracted_content) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-14-3)     print(data)`

### 5.2 **`downloaded_files`** _(Optional\[List\[str\]\])_

**What**: If `accept_downloads=True` in your `BrowserConfig` + `downloads_path`, lists local file paths for downloaded items.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-15-1) if result.downloaded_files: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-15-2)     for file_path in result.downloaded_files: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-15-3)         print("Downloaded:", file_path)`

### 5.3 **`screenshot`** _(Optional\[str\])_

**What**: Base64-encoded screenshot if `screenshot=True` in `CrawlerRunConfig`.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-16-1) import base64 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-16-2) if result.screenshot: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-16-3)     with open("page.png", "wb") as f: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-16-4)         f.write(base64.b64decode(result.screenshot))`

### 5.4 **`pdf`** _(Optional\[bytes\])_

**What**: Raw PDF bytes if `pdf=True` in `CrawlerRunConfig`.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-17-1) if result.pdf: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-17-2)     with open("page.pdf", "wb") as f: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-17-3)         f.write(result.pdf)`

### 5.5 **`mhtml`** _(Optional\[str\])_

**What**: MHTML snapshot of the page if `capture_mhtml=True` in `CrawlerRunConfig`. MHTML (MIME HTML) format preserves the entire web page with all its resources (CSS, images, scripts, etc.) in a single file.  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-18-1) if result.mhtml: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-18-2)     with open("page.mhtml", "w", encoding="utf-8") as f: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-18-3)         f.write(result.mhtml)`

### 5.6 **`metadata`** _(Optional\[dict\])_

**What**: Page-level metadata if discovered (title, description, OG data, etc.).  
**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-19-1) if result.metadata: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-19-2)     print("Title:", result.metadata.get("title")) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-19-3)     print("Author:", result.metadata.get("author"))`

* * *

6\. `dispatch_result` (optional)
--------------------------------

A `DispatchResult` object providing additional concurrency and resource usage information when crawling URLs in parallel (e.g., via `arun_many()` with custom dispatchers). It contains:

*   **`task_id`**: A unique identifier for the parallel task.
*   **`memory_usage`** (float): The memory (in MB) used at the time of completion.
*   **`peak_memory`** (float): The peak memory usage (in MB) recorded during the task's execution.
*   **`start_time`** / **`end_time`** (datetime): Time range for this crawling task.
*   **`error_message`** (str): Any dispatcher- or concurrency-related error encountered.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-20-1) # Example usage: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-20-2) for result in results: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-20-3)     if result.success and result.dispatch_result: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-20-4)         dr = result.dispatch_result [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-20-5)         print(f"URL: {result.url}, Task ID: {dr.task_id}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-20-6)         print(f"Memory: {dr.memory_usage:.1f} MB (Peak: {dr.peak_memory:.1f} MB)") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-20-7)         print(f"Duration: {dr.end_time - dr.start_time}")`

> **Note**: This field is typically populated when using `arun_many(...)` alongside a **dispatcher** (e.g., `MemoryAdaptiveDispatcher` or `SemaphoreDispatcher`). If no concurrency or dispatcher is used, `dispatch_result` may remain `None`.

* * *

7\. Network Requests & Console Messages
---------------------------------------

When you enable network and console message capturing in `CrawlerRunConfig` using `capture_network_requests=True` and `capture_console_messages=True`, the `CrawlResult` will include these fields:

### 7.1 **`network_requests`** _(Optional\[List\[Dict\[str, Any\]\]\])_

**What**: A list of dictionaries containing information about all network requests, responses, and failures captured during the crawl. **Structure**: - Each item has an `event_type` field that can be `"request"`, `"response"`, or `"request_failed"`. - Request events include `url`, `method`, `headers`, `post_data`, `resource_type`, and `is_navigation_request`. - Response events include `url`, `status`, `status_text`, `headers`, and `request_timing`. - Failed request events include `url`, `method`, `resource_type`, and `failure_text`. - All events include a `timestamp` field.

**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-1) if result.network_requests: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-2)     # Count different types of events [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-3)     requests = [r for r in result.network_requests if r.get("event_type") == "request"] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-4)     responses = [r for r in result.network_requests if r.get("event_type") == "response"] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-5)     failures = [r for r in result.network_requests if r.get("event_type") == "request_failed"] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-7)     print(f"Captured {len(requests)} requests, {len(responses)} responses, and {len(failures)} failures") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-9)     # Analyze API calls [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-10)     api_calls = [r for r in requests if "api" in r.get("url", "")] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-11) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-12)     # Identify failed resources [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-13)     for failure in failures: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-21-14)         print(f"Failed to load: {failure.get('url')} - {failure.get('failure_text')}")`

### 7.2 **`console_messages`** _(Optional\[List\[Dict\[str, Any\]\]\])_

**What**: A list of dictionaries containing all browser console messages captured during the crawl. **Structure**: - Each item has a `type` field indicating the message type (e.g., `"log"`, `"error"`, `"warning"`, etc.). - The `text` field contains the actual message text. - Some messages include `location` information (URL, line, column). - All messages include a `timestamp` field.

**Usage**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-1) if result.console_messages: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-2)     # Count messages by type [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-3)     message_types = {} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-4)     for msg in result.console_messages: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-5)         msg_type = msg.get("type", "unknown") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-6)         message_types[msg_type] = message_types.get(msg_type, 0) + 1 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-8)     print(f"Message type counts: {message_types}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-9) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-10)     # Display errors (which are usually most important) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-11)     for msg in result.console_messages: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-12)         if msg.get("type") == "error": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/crawl-result/#__codelineno-22-13)             print(f"Error: {msg.get('text')}")`

These fields provide deep visibility into the page's network activity and browser console, which is invaluable for debugging, security analysis, and understanding complex web applications.

For more details on network and console capturing, see the [Network & Console Capture documentation](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/network-console-capture/)
.

9\. Key Points & Future
-----------------------

1. **Deprecated legacy properties of CrawlResult**  
\- `markdown_v2` - Deprecated in v0.5. Just use `markdown`. It holds the `MarkdownGenerationResult` now! - `fit_markdown` and `fit_html` - Deprecated in v0.5. They can now be accessed via `MarkdownGenerationResult` in `result.markdown`. eg: `result.markdown.fit_markdown` and `result.markdown.fit_html`

2. **Fit Content**  
\- **`fit_markdown`** and **`fit_html`** appear in MarkdownGenerationResult, only if you used a content filter (like **PruningContentFilter** or **BM25ContentFilter**) inside your **MarkdownGenerationStrategy** or set them directly.  
\- If no filter is used, they remain `None`.

3. **References & Citations**  
\- If you enable link citations in your `DefaultMarkdownGenerator` (`options={"citations": True}`), you’ll see `markdown_with_citations` plus a **`references_markdown`** block. This helps large language models or academic-like referencing.

4. **Links & Media**  
\- `links["internal"]` and `links["external"]` group discovered anchors by domain.  
\- `media["images"]` / `["videos"]` / `["audios"]` store extracted media elements with optional scoring or context.

5. **Error Cases**  
\- If `success=False`, check `error_message` (e.g., timeouts, invalid URLs).  
\- `status_code` might be `None` if we failed before an HTTP response.

Use **`CrawlResult`** to glean all final outputs and feed them into your data pipelines, AI models, or archives. With the synergy of a properly configured **BrowserConfig** and **CrawlerRunConfig**, the crawler can produce robust, structured results here in **`CrawlResult`**.

* * *

# Installation 💻 - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Installation 💻
===============

Crawl4AI offers flexible installation options to suit various use cases. You can install it as a Python package, use it with Docker, or run it as a local server.

Option 1: Python Package Installation (Recommended)
---------------------------------------------------

Crawl4AI is now available on PyPI, making installation easier than ever. Choose the option that best fits your needs:

### Basic Installation

For basic web crawling and scraping tasks:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/basic/installation/#__codelineno-0-1) pip install crawl4ai [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/basic/installation/#__codelineno-0-2) playwright install # Install Playwright dependencies`

### Installation with PyTorch

For advanced text clustering (includes CosineSimilarity cluster strategy):

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/basic/installation/#__codelineno-1-1) pip install crawl4ai[torch]`

### Installation with Transformers

For text summarization and Hugging Face models:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/basic/installation/#__codelineno-2-1) pip install crawl4ai[transformer]`

### Full Installation

For all features:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/basic/installation/#__codelineno-3-1) pip install crawl4ai[all]`

### Development Installation

For contributors who plan to modify the source code:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/basic/installation/#__codelineno-4-1) git clone https://github.com/unclecode/crawl4ai.git [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/basic/installation/#__codelineno-4-2) cd crawl4ai [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/basic/installation/#__codelineno-4-3) pip install -e ".[all]" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/basic/installation/#__codelineno-4-4) playwright install # Install Playwright dependencies`

💡 After installation with "torch", "transformer", or "all" options, it's recommended to run the following CLI command to load the required models:

# Build - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

O**Prompt for AI Coding Assistant: Create an Interactive LLM Context Builder Page**

**Objective:**

Your task is to create an interactive HTML webpage with JavaScript functionality that allows users to select and combine different `crawl4ai` LLM context files into a single downloadable Markdown (`.md`) file. This tool will empower users to craft tailored context for their AI assistants based on their specific needs.

**Core Functionality:**

1.  **Display `crawl4ai` Components:** The page will list all available `crawl4ai` documentation components.
2.  **Select Context Types:** For each component, users can select which types of context they want to include:
    *   Memory (API facts)
    *   Reasoning (How-to/why)
    *   Examples (Code snippets) (All should be selected by default for each initially selected component).
3.  **Special "Aggregate" Contexts:** Include options for special, pre-combined contexts:
    *   "Vibe Coding" (a curated mix for general AI prompting)
    *   "All Library Context" (a comprehensive aggregation of all memory, reasoning, and examples for the entire library).
4.  **Fetch and Concatenate:** When the user clicks a "Download Combined Context" button:
    *   The JavaScript will fetch the content of all selected Markdown files from the server (from a predefined folder, e.g., `/llmtxt/`).
    *   It will concatenate the content of these files into a single string.
5.  **Client-Side Download:** The concatenated content will be offered to the user as a download (e.g., `custom_crawl4ai_context.md`).

**Input/Assumptions:**

*   **Context Files Location:** All individual context Markdown files are located on the server in a publicly accessible folder named `llmtxt/`.
*   **File Naming Convention:** Files follow the pattern: `crawl4ai_{{component_name}}_[memory|reasoning|examples]_content.llm.md`.
    *   `{{component_name}}` can contain underscores (e.g., `deep_crawling`, `config_objects`).
    *   The special contexts will have names like `crawl4ai_vibe_content.llm.md` and `crawl4ai_all_content.llm.md`.
*   **Component List:** You will be provided with a list of `crawl4ai` components. For this implementation, use the following list:
    *   `core`
    *   `config_objects`
    *   `deep_crawling`
    *   `deployment` (covers Installation & Docker Deployment)
    *   `extraction` (covers Structured Data Extraction)
    *   `markdown` (covers Markdown Generation Algorithm)
    *   `pdf_processing`
    *   _(No separate "Vibe Coding" or "All Library Context" in this list, as they are special top-level selections)_

**Detailed UI/UX Requirements:**

1.  **Main Page Structure:**
    *   **Header:** "Crawl4AI Interactive LLM Context Builder"
    *   **Introduction:** Briefly explain the purpose of the tool (from the `USING_LLM_CONTEXTS.md` content you helped draft: "Supercharging Your AI Assistant...").
    *   **Selection Area:**
        *   **Special Aggregate Contexts (Radio Buttons or Prominent Checkboxes):**
            *   \[ \] "Vibe Coding Context" (`crawl4ai_vibe_content.llm.md`)
            *   \[ \] "All Library Context (Comprehensive)" (`crawl4ai_all_content.llm.md`)
            *   _Behavior:_ Selecting one of these might disable individual component selections (or vice-versa) to avoid redundancy, or simply add them to the list. Consider user experience here. A simple approach is that if an aggregate is selected, it's the _only_ thing downloaded.
        *   **Individual Component Selection (Table or List of Checkboxes):**
            *   A section titled "Select Individual Components & Context Types:"
            *   For each component in the provided list:
                *   A master checkbox for the component itself (e.g., `[ ] Core Functionality`). Selected by default.
                *   Nested checkboxes (indented or grouped) for context types, enabled only if the parent component is checked:
                    *   `[x] Memory (API Facts)`
                    *   `[x] Reasoning (How-to/Why)`
                    *   `[x] Examples (Code Snippets)` (These three sub-checkboxes should be selected by default if the parent component is selected).
    *   **Action Button:**
        *   A button: "Generate & Download Combined Context"
    *   **Status/Feedback Area:** (Optional, but good UX)
        *   Display messages like "Fetching files...", "Combining context...", "Download starting..." or error messages.

**Final Output:**

*   A single HTML file (e.g., `interactive_context_builder.html`).
*   Associated JavaScript code (can be inline within `<script>` tags or in a separate `.js` file).
*   Associated CSS code (can be inline within `<style>` tags or in a separate `.css` file).

This interactive tool will greatly enhance the user experience for `crawl4ai` developers looking to leverage your specialized LLM contexts. Please ensure the JavaScript is robust and provides good user feedback.

* * *

This prompt should give your AI coding assistant a very clear set of requirements and guidelines for building the interactive context builder. Remember to provide it with the list of components as mentioned in the "Input/Assumptions" section.

# Supercharging Your AI Assistant: My Journey to Better LLM Contexts for crawl4ai - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Supercharging Your AI Assistant: My Journey to Better LLM Contexts for `crawl4ai`
=================================================================================

When I started diving deep into using AI coding assistants with my own libraries, particularly `crawl4ai`, I quickly realized that the common approach to providing context via a simple `llm.txt` or even a beefed-up `README.md` just wasn't cutting it. This document explains the problems I encountered and how I've tried to create a more effective system for `crawl4ai`, allowing you (and your AI assistant) to get precisely the right information.

My Frustration with Standard `llm.txt` Files
--------------------------------------------

My experience with generic `llm.txt` files for complex libraries like `crawl4ai` revealed several pain points:

1.  **Information Overload & Lost Focus:** I found that when I threw a massive, monolithic context file at an LLM, it often struggled. The sheer volume of information seemed to dilute its focus. If I asked a specific question about a niche feature, the LLM might get sidetracked by more prominent but currently irrelevant parts of the library. It felt like trying to find a single sentence in a thousand-page novel – the information was _there_, but not always accessible or prioritized correctly by the AI.
    
2.  **The "What" Without the "How" or "Why":** Most `llm.txt` files I encountered were essentially API dumps – a list of functions, classes, and parameters. This is the "what" of a library. But to truly use a library effectively, especially one as flexible as `crawl4ai`, you need the "how" (idiomatic usage patterns, best practices for common tasks) and the "why" (the design rationale behind certain features). Without this, I noticed my AI assistant would often generate syntactically correct but practically inefficient or non-idiomatic code. It was guessing the _intent_ and the _best way_ to use the library, and those guesses weren't always right.
    
3.  **No Guidance on "Thinking" Like an Expert:** A static list of facts doesn't teach an LLM the _art_ of using the library. It doesn't convey the trade-offs an experienced developer considers, the common pitfalls they've learned to avoid, or the clever ways to combine features to solve complex problems. I wanted my AI assistant to not just recall an API, but to help me _reason_ about the best way to build a solution with `crawl4ai`.
    

Inspiration: Selective Inclusion & Multi-Dimensional Understanding
------------------------------------------------------------------

I've always admired how libraries like Lodash or jQuery (in its modular days) allowed developers to pick and choose only the parts they needed, resulting in smaller, more focused bundles. This idea of modularity and selective inclusion resonated deeply with me as I thought about LLM context. Why force-feed an LLM the entire library's details when I'm only working on a specific component or task?

This led me to develop a new approach for `crawl4ai`: **multi-dimensional, modular contexts**.

Instead of one giant `llm.txt`, I've broken down the `crawl4ai` documentation into:

1.  **Logical Components:** Context is organized around the major functional areas of the library (e.g., Core, Data Extraction, Deep Crawling, Markdown Generation, etc.). This allows you to select context relevant only to the task at hand.
2.  **Three Dimensions of Context for Each Component:**
    *   **`_memory.md` (Foundational Memory):** This is the "what." It contains the precise, factual information about the component's public API, data structures, configuration objects, parameters, and method signatures. It's the detailed, unambiguous reference.
    *   **`_reasoning.md` (Reasoning & Problem-Solving Framework):** This is the "how" and "why." It includes design principles, common task workflows with decision guides, best practices, anti-patterns, illustrative code examples solving real problems, and explanations of trade-offs. It aims to guide the LLM in "thinking" like an expert `crawl4ai` user.
    *   **`_examples.md` (Practical Code Examples):** This is pure "show-me-the-code." It's a collection of runnable snippets demonstrating various ways to use the component's features and configurations, with minimal explanatory text. It’s for quickly seeing different patterns in action.

**The Goal:** My aim is to provide you with a flexible system. You can give your AI assistant: \* Just the **memory** files for quick API lookups. \* The **reasoning** files (perhaps with memory) for help designing solutions. \* The **examples** files for seeing practical implementations. \* A **combination** of these across one or more components tailored to your specific task. \* Or, for broader understanding, special aggregate contexts like the "Vibe Coding" context or the "All Library Context."

By providing these structured, multi-faceted contexts, I hope to significantly improve the quality and relevance of the assistance you get when using AI to code with `crawl4ai`. The following sections will guide you on how to select and use these different context files.

# Release Summary for Version 0.4.0 (December 1, 2024) - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Release Summary for Version 0.4.0 (December 1, 2024)
====================================================

Overview
--------

The 0.4.0 release introduces significant improvements to content filtering, multi-threaded environment handling, user-agent generation, and test coverage. Key highlights include the introduction of the PruningContentFilter, designed to automatically identify and extract the most valuable parts of an HTML document, as well as enhancements to the BM25ContentFilter to extend its versatility and effectiveness.

Major Features and Enhancements
-------------------------------

### 1\. PruningContentFilter

*   Introduced a new unsupervised content filtering strategy that scores and prunes less relevant nodes in an HTML document based on metrics like text and link density.
*   Focuses on retaining the most valuable parts of the content, making it highly effective for extracting relevant information from complex web pages.
*   Fully documented with updated README and expanded user guides.

### 2\. User-Agent Generator

*   Added a user-agent generator utility that resolves compatibility issues and supports customizable user-agent strings.
*   By default, the generator randomizes user agents for each request, adding diversity, but users can customize it for tailored scenarios.

### 3\. Enhanced Thread Safety

*   Improved handling of multi-threaded environments by adding better thread locks for parallel processing, ensuring consistency and stability when running multiple threads.

### 4\. Extended Content Filtering Strategies

*   Users now have access to both the PruningContentFilter for unsupervised extraction and the BM25ContentFilter for supervised filtering based on user queries.
*   Enhanced BM25ContentFilter with improved capabilities to process page titles, meta tags, and descriptions, allowing for more effective classification and clustering of text chunks.

### 5\. Documentation Updates

*   Updated examples and tutorials to promote the use of the PruningContentFilter alongside the BM25ContentFilter, providing clear instructions for selecting the appropriate filter for each use case.

### 6\. Unit Test Enhancements

*   Added unit tests for PruningContentFilter to ensure accuracy and reliability.
*   Enhanced BM25ContentFilter tests to cover additional edge cases and performance metrics, particularly for malformed HTML inputs.

Revised Change Logs for Version 0.4.0
-------------------------------------

### PruningContentFilter (Dec 01, 2024)

*   Introduced the PruningContentFilter to optimize content extraction by pruning less relevant HTML nodes.
*   **Affected Files:**
    *   **crawl4ai/content\_filter\_strategy.py**: Added a scoring-based pruning algorithm.
    *   **README.md**: Updated to include PruningContentFilter usage.
    *   **docs/md\_v2/basic/content\_filtering.md**: Expanded user documentation, detailing the use and benefits of PruningContentFilter.

### Unit Tests for PruningContentFilter (Dec 01, 2024)

*   Added comprehensive unit tests for PruningContentFilter to ensure correctness and efficiency.
*   **Affected Files:**
    *   **tests/async/test\_content\_filter\_prune.py**: Created tests covering different pruning scenarios to ensure stability and correctness.

### Enhanced BM25ContentFilter Tests (Dec 01, 2024)

*   Expanded tests to cover additional extraction scenarios and performance metrics, improving robustness.
*   **Affected Files:**
    *   **tests/async/test\_content\_filter\_bm25.py**: Added tests for edge cases, including malformed HTML inputs.

### Documentation and Example Updates (Dec 01, 2024)

*   Revised examples to illustrate the use of PruningContentFilter alongside existing content filtering methods.
*   **Affected Files:**
    *   **docs/examples/quickstart\_async.py**: Enhanced example clarity and usability for new users.

Experimental Features
---------------------

*   The PruningContentFilter is still under experimental development, and we continue to gather feedback for further refinements.

Conclusion
----------

This release significantly enhances the content extraction capabilities of Crawl4ai with the introduction of the PruningContentFilter, improved supervised filtering with BM25ContentFilter, and robust multi-threaded handling. Additionally, the user-agent generator provides much-needed versatility, resolving compatibility issues faced by many users.

Users are encouraged to experiment with the new content filtering methods to determine which best suits their needs.

# Dockerize hooks - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Introducing Event Streams and Interactive Hooks in Crawl4AI
-----------------------------------------------------------

![event-driven-crawl](https://res.cloudinary.com/kidocode/image/upload/t_400x400/v1734344008/15bb8bbb-83ac-43ac-962d-3feb3e0c3bbf_2_tjmr4n.webp)

In the near future, I’m planning to enhance Crawl4AI’s capabilities by introducing an event stream mechanism that will give clients deeper, real-time insights into the crawling process. Today, hooks are a powerful feature at the code level—they let developers define custom logic at key points in the crawl. However, when using Crawl4AI as a service (e.g., through a Dockerized API), there isn’t an easy way to interact with these hooks at runtime.

**What’s Changing?**

I’m working on a solution that will allow the crawler to emit a continuous stream of events, updating clients on the current crawling stage, encountered pages, and any decision points. This event stream could be exposed over a standardized protocol like Server-Sent Events (SSE) or WebSockets, enabling clients to “subscribe” and listen as the crawler works.

**Interactivity Through Process IDs**

A key part of this new design is the concept of a unique process ID for each crawl session. Imagine you’re listening to an event stream that informs you: - The crawler just hit a certain page  
\- It triggered a hook and is now pausing for instructions

With the event stream in place, you can send a follow-up request back to the server—referencing the unique process ID—to provide extra data, instructions, or parameters. This might include selecting which links to follow next, adjusting extraction strategies, or providing authentication tokens for a protected API. Once the crawler receives these instructions, it resumes execution with the updated context.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-1) sequenceDiagram [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-2)     participant Client [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-3)     participant Server [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-4)     participant Crawler [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-6)     Client->>Server: Start crawl request [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-7)     Server->>Crawler: Initiate crawl with Process ID [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-8)     Crawler-->>Server: Event: Page hit [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-9)     Server-->>Client: Stream: Page hit event [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-10)     Client->>Server: Instruction for Process ID [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-11)     Server->>Crawler: Update crawl with new instructions [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-12)     Crawler-->>Server: Event: Crawl completed [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/dockerize_hooks/#__codelineno-0-13)     Server-->>Client: Stream: Crawl completed`

**Benefits for Developers and Users**

1. **Fine-Grained Control**: Instead of predefining all logic upfront, you can dynamically guide the crawler in response to actual data and conditions encountered mid-crawl. 2. **Real-Time Insights**: Monitor progress, errors, or network bottlenecks as they happen, without waiting for the entire crawl to finish. 3. **Enhanced Collaboration**: Different team members or automated systems can watch the same crawl events and provide input, making the crawling process more adaptive and intelligent.

**Next Steps**

I’m currently exploring the best APIs, technologies, and patterns to make this vision a reality. My goal is to deliver a seamless developer experience—one that integrates with existing Crawl4AI workflows while offering new flexibility and power.

Stay tuned for more updates as I continue building this feature out. In the meantime, I’d love to hear any feedback or suggestions you might have to help shape this interactive, event-driven future of web crawling with Crawl4AI.

* * *
