# Adaptive Crawling: Building Dynamic Knowledge That Grows on Demand - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Adaptive Crawling: Building Dynamic Knowledge That Grows on Demand
==================================================================

_Published on January 29, 2025 • 8 min read_

_By [unclecode](https://x.com/unclecode)
 • Follow me on [X/Twitter](https://x.com/unclecode)
 for more web scraping insights_

* * *

The Knowledge Capacitor
-----------------------

Imagine a capacitor that stores energy, releasing it precisely when needed. Now imagine that for information. That's Adaptive Crawling—a term I coined to describe a fundamentally different approach to web crawling. Instead of the brute force of traditional deep crawling, we build knowledge dynamically, growing it based on queries and circumstances, like a living organism responding to its environment.

This isn't just another crawling optimization. It's a paradigm shift from "crawl everything, hope for the best" to "crawl intelligently, know when to stop."

Why I Built This
----------------

I've watched too many startups burn through resources with a dangerous misconception: that LLMs make everything efficient. They don't. They make things _possible_, not necessarily _smart_. When you combine brute-force crawling with LLM processing, you're not just wasting time—you're hemorrhaging money on tokens, compute, and opportunity cost.

Consider this reality: - **Traditional deep crawling**: 500 pages → 50 useful → $15 in LLM tokens → 2 hours wasted - **Adaptive crawling**: 15 pages → 14 useful → $2 in tokens → 10 minutes → **7.5x cost reduction**

But it's not about crawling less. It's about crawling _right_.

The Information Theory Foundation
---------------------------------

\### 🧮 \*\*Pure Statistics, No Magic\*\* My first principle was crucial: start with classic statistical approaches. No embeddings. No LLMs. Just pure information theory:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-0-1) # Information gain calculation - the heart of adaptive crawling [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-0-2) def calculate_information_gain(new_page, knowledge_base): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-0-3)     new_terms = extract_terms(new_page) - existing_terms(knowledge_base) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-0-4)     overlap = calculate_overlap(new_page, knowledge_base) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-0-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-0-6)     # High gain = many new terms + low overlap [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-0-7)     gain = len(new_terms) / (1 + overlap) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-0-8)     return gain`

This isn't regression to older methods—it's recognition that we've forgotten powerful, efficient solutions in our rush to apply LLMs everywhere.

The A\* of Web Crawling
-----------------------

Adaptive crawling implements what I call "information scenting"—like A\* pathfinding but for knowledge acquisition. Each link is evaluated not randomly, but by its probability of contributing meaningful information toward answering current and future queries.

🎯

**The Scenting Algorithm:**  
From available links, we select those with highest information gain. It's not about following every path—it's about following the _right_ paths. Like a bloodhound following the strongest scent to its target.

The Three Pillars of Intelligence
---------------------------------

### 1\. Coverage: The Breadth Sensor

Measures how well your knowledge spans the query space. Not just "do we have pages?" but "do we have the RIGHT pages?"

### 2\. Consistency: The Coherence Detector

Information from multiple sources should align. When pages agree, confidence rises. When they conflict, we need more data.

### 3\. Saturation: The Efficiency Guardian

The most crucial metric. When new pages stop adding information, we stop crawling. Simple. Powerful. Ignored by everyone else.

Real Impact: Time, Money, and Sanity
------------------------------------

Let me show you what this means for your bottom line:

### Building a Customer Support Knowledge Base

**Traditional Approach:**

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-1-1) # Crawl entire documentation site [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-1-2) results = await crawler.crawl_bfs("https://docs.company.com", max_depth=5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-1-3) # Result: 1,200 pages, 18 hours, $150 in API costs [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-1-4) # Useful content: ~100 pages scattered throughout`

**Adaptive Approach:**

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-2-1) # Grow knowledge based on actual support queries [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-2-2) knowledge = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-2-3)     start_url="https://docs.company.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-2-4)     query="payment processing errors refund policies" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-2-5) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-2-6) # Result: 45 pages, 12 minutes, $8 in API costs [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-2-7) # Useful content: 42 pages, all relevant`

**Savings: 93% time reduction, 95% cost reduction, 100% more sanity**

The Dynamic Growth Pattern
--------------------------

Knowledge grows like crystals in a supersaturated solution

Add a query (seed), and relevant information crystallizes around it.  
Change the query, and the knowledge structure adapts.

This is the beauty of adaptive crawling: your knowledge base becomes a living entity that grows based on actual needs, not hypothetical completeness.

Why "Adaptive"?
---------------

I specifically chose "Adaptive" because it captures the essence: the system adapts to what it finds. Dense technical documentation might need 20 pages for confidence. A simple FAQ might need just 5. The crawler doesn't follow a recipe—it reads the room and adjusts.

This is my term, my concept, and I have extensive plans for its evolution.

The Progressive Roadmap
-----------------------

This is just the beginning. My roadmap for Adaptive Crawling:

### Phase 1 (Current): Statistical Foundation

*   Pure information theory approach
*   No dependencies on expensive models
*   Proven efficiency gains

### Phase 2 (Now Available): Embedding Enhancement

*   Semantic understanding layered onto statistical base
*   Still efficient, now even smarter
*   Optional, not required

### Phase 3 (Future): LLM Integration

*   LLMs for complex reasoning tasks only
*   Used surgically, not wastefully
*   Always with statistical foundation underneath

The Efficiency Revolution
-------------------------

\### 💰 \*\*The Economics of Intelligence\*\* For a typical SaaS documentation crawl: \*\*Traditional Deep Crawling:\*\* - Pages crawled: 1,000 - Useful pages: 80 - Time spent: 3 hours - LLM tokens used: 2.5M - Cost: $75 - Efficiency: 8% \*\*Adaptive Crawling:\*\* - Pages crawled: 95 - Useful pages: 88 - Time spent: 15 minutes - LLM tokens used: 200K - Cost: $6 - Efficiency: 93% \*\*That's not optimization. That's transformation.\*\*

Missing the Forest for the Trees
--------------------------------

The startup world has a dangerous blind spot. We're so enamored with LLMs that we forget: just because you CAN process everything with an LLM doesn't mean you SHOULD.

Classic NLP and statistical methods can: - Filter irrelevant content before it reaches LLMs - Identify patterns without expensive inference - Make intelligent decisions in microseconds - Scale without breaking the bank

Adaptive crawling proves this. It uses battle-tested information theory to make smart decisions BEFORE expensive processing.

Your Knowledge, On Demand
-------------------------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-1) # Monday: Customer asks about authentication [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-2) auth_knowledge = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-3)     "https://docs.api.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-4)     "oauth jwt authentication" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-5) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-7) # Tuesday: They ask about rate limiting [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-8) # The crawler adapts, builds on existing knowledge [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-9) rate_limit_knowledge = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-10)     "https://docs.api.com",  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-11)     "rate limiting throttling quotas" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-12) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-3-14) # Your knowledge base grows intelligently, not indiscriminately`

The Competitive Edge
--------------------

Companies using adaptive crawling will have: - **90% lower crawling costs** - **Knowledge bases that actually answer questions** - **Update cycles in minutes, not days** - **Happy customers who find answers fast** - **Engineers who sleep at night**

Those still using brute force? They'll wonder why their infrastructure costs keep rising while their customers keep complaining.

The Embedding Evolution (Now Available!)
----------------------------------------

\### 🧠 \*\*Semantic Understanding Without the Cost\*\* The embedding strategy brings semantic intelligence while maintaining efficiency:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-1) # Statistical strategy - great for exact terms [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-2) config_statistical = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-3)     strategy="statistical"  # Default [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-4) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-6) # Embedding strategy - understands concepts [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-7) config_embedding = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-8)     strategy="embedding", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-9)     embedding_model="sentence-transformers/all-MiniLM-L6-v2", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-10)     n_query_variations=10 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-4-11) )`

\*\*The magic\*\*: It automatically expands your query into semantic variations, maps the coverage space, and identifies gaps to fill intelligently.

### Real-World Comparison

\*\*Query\*\*: "authentication oauth" \*\*Statistical Strategy\*\*: - Searches for exact terms - 12 pages crawled - 78% confidence - Fast but literal

\*\*Embedding Strategy\*\*: - Understands "auth", "login", "SSO" - 8 pages crawled - 92% confidence - Semantic comprehension

### Detecting Irrelevance

One killer feature: the embedding strategy knows when to give up:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-5-1) # Crawling Python docs with a cooking query [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-5-2) result = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-5-3)     start_url="https://docs.python.org/3/", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-5-4)     query="how to make spaghetti carbonara" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-5-5) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-5-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-5-7) # System detects irrelevance and stops [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-5-8) # Confidence: 5% (below threshold) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-5-9) # Pages crawled: 2 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-5-10) # Stopped reason: "below_minimum_relevance_threshold"`

No more crawling hundreds of pages hoping to find something that doesn't exist!

Try It Yourself
---------------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-1) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, AdaptiveCrawler, AdaptiveConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-3) async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-4)     # Choose your strategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-5)     config = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-6)         strategy="embedding",  # or "statistical" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-7)         embedding_min_confidence_threshold=0.1  # Stop if irrelevant [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-8)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-9) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-10)     adaptive = AdaptiveCrawler(crawler, config) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-11) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-12)     # Watch intelligence at work [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-13)     result = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-14)         start_url="https://your-docs.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-15)         query="your users' actual questions" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-16)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-17) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-18)     # See the efficiency [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-19)     adaptive.print_stats() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-20)     print(f"Found {adaptive.confidence:.0%} of needed information") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-21)     print(f"In just {len(result.crawled_urls)} pages") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/adaptive-crawling-revolution/#__codelineno-6-22)     print(f"Saving you {1000 - len(result.crawled_urls)} unnecessary crawls")`

A Personal Note
---------------

I created Adaptive Crawling because I was tired of watching smart people make inefficient choices. We have incredibly powerful statistical tools that we've forgotten in our rush toward LLMs. This is my attempt to bring balance back to the Force.

This is not just a feature. It's a philosophy: **Grow knowledge on demand. Stop when you have enough. Save time, money, and computational resources for what really matters.**

The Future is Adaptive
----------------------

Traditional Crawling: Drinking from a firehose  
Adaptive Crawling: Sipping exactly what you need

The future of web crawling isn't about processing more data.  
It's about processing the _right_ data.

Join me in making web crawling intelligent, efficient, and actually useful. Because in the age of information overload, the winners won't be those who collect the most data—they'll be those who collect the _right_ data.

# digest() - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

digest()
========

The `digest()` method is the primary interface for adaptive web crawling. It intelligently crawls websites starting from a given URL, guided by a query, and automatically determines when sufficient information has been gathered.

Method Signature
----------------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-0-1) async def digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-0-2)     start_url: str, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-0-3)     query: str, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-0-4)     resume_from: Optional[Union[str, Path]] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-0-5) ) -> CrawlState`

Parameters
----------

### start\_url

*   **Type**: `str`
*   **Required**: Yes
*   **Description**: The starting URL for the crawl. This should be a valid HTTP/HTTPS URL that serves as the entry point for information gathering.

### query

*   **Type**: `str`
*   **Required**: Yes
*   **Description**: The search query that guides the crawling process. This should contain key terms related to the information you're seeking. The crawler uses this to evaluate relevance and determine which links to follow.

### resume\_from

*   **Type**: `Optional[Union[str, Path]]`
*   **Default**: `None`
*   **Description**: Path to a previously saved crawl state file. When provided, the crawler resumes from the saved state instead of starting fresh.

Return Value
------------

Returns a `CrawlState` object containing:

*   **crawled\_urls** (`Set[str]`): All URLs that have been crawled
*   **knowledge\_base** (`List[CrawlResult]`): Collection of crawled pages with content
*   **pending\_links** (`List[Link]`): Links discovered but not yet crawled
*   **metrics** (`Dict[str, float]`): Performance and quality metrics
*   **query** (`str`): The original query
*   Additional statistical information for scoring

How It Works
------------

The `digest()` method implements an intelligent crawling algorithm:

1.  **Initial Crawl**: Starts from the provided URL
2.  **Link Analysis**: Evaluates all discovered links for relevance
3.  **Scoring**: Uses three metrics to assess information sufficiency:
4.  **Coverage**: How well the query terms are covered
5.  **Consistency**: Information coherence across pages
6.  **Saturation**: Diminishing returns detection
7.  **Adaptive Selection**: Chooses the most promising links to follow
8.  **Stopping Decision**: Automatically stops when confidence threshold is reached

Examples
--------

### Basic Usage

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-1-1) async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-1-2)     adaptive = AdaptiveCrawler(crawler) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-1-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-1-4)     state = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-1-5)         start_url="https://docs.python.org/3/", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-1-6)         query="async await context managers" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-1-7)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-1-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-1-9)     print(f"Crawled {len(state.crawled_urls)} pages") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-1-10)     print(f"Confidence: {adaptive.confidence:.0%}")`

### With Configuration

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-1) config = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-2)     confidence_threshold=0.9,  # Require high confidence [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-3)     max_pages=30,             # Allow more pages [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-4)     top_k_links=3             # Follow top 3 links per page [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-5) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-7) adaptive = AdaptiveCrawler(crawler, config=config) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-9) state = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-10)     start_url="https://api.example.com/docs", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-11)     query="authentication endpoints rate limits" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-2-12) )`

### Resuming a Previous Crawl

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-1) # First crawl - may be interrupted [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-2) state1 = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-3)     start_url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-4)     query="machine learning algorithms" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-5) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-7) # Save state (if not auto-saved) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-8) state1.save("ml_crawl_state.json") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-9) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-10) # Later, resume from saved state [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-11) state2 = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-12)     start_url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-13)     query="machine learning algorithms", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-14)     resume_from="ml_crawl_state.json" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-3-15) )`

### With Progress Monitoring

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-1) state = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-2)     start_url="https://docs.example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-3)     query="api reference" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-4) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-6) # Monitor progress [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-7) print(f"Pages crawled: {len(state.crawled_urls)}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-8) print(f"New terms discovered: {state.new_terms_history}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-9) print(f"Final confidence: {adaptive.confidence:.2%}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-11) # View detailed statistics [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-4-12) adaptive.print_stats(detailed=True)`

Query Best Practices
--------------------

1.  **Be Specific**: Use descriptive terms that appear in target content
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-5-1) # Good [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-5-2) query = "python async context managers implementation" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-5-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-5-4) # Too broad [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-5-5) query = "python programming"`
    
2.  **Include Key Terms**: Add technical terms you expect to find
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-6-1) query = "oauth2 jwt refresh tokens authorization"`
    
3.  **Multiple Concepts**: Combine related concepts for comprehensive coverage
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-7-1) query = "rest api pagination sorting filtering"`
    

Performance Considerations
--------------------------

*   **Initial URL**: Choose a page with good navigation (e.g., documentation index)
*   **Query Length**: 3-8 terms typically work best
*   **Link Density**: Sites with clear navigation crawl more efficiently
*   **Caching**: Enable caching for repeated crawls of the same domain

Error Handling
--------------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-8-1) try: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-8-2)     state = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-8-3)         start_url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-8-4)         query="search terms" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-8-5)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-8-6) except Exception as e: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-8-7)     print(f"Crawl failed: {e}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/digest/#__codelineno-8-8)     # State is auto-saved if save_state=True in config`

Stopping Conditions
-------------------

The crawl stops when any of these conditions are met:

1.  **Confidence Threshold**: Reached the configured confidence level
2.  **Page Limit**: Crawled the maximum number of pages
3.  **Diminishing Returns**: Expected information gain below threshold
4.  **No Relevant Links**: No promising links remain to follow

--------

*   [Adaptive Crawling Guide](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/adaptive-crawling/)
    
*   [Configuration Options](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/adaptive-crawling/#configuration-options)

# The LLM Context Protocol: Why Your AI Assistant Needs Memory, Reasoning, and Examples - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

The LLM Context Protocol: Why Your AI Assistant Needs Memory, Reasoning, and Examples
=====================================================================================

_Published on January 24, 2025 • 8 min read_

* * *

The Problem with Teaching Robots to Code
----------------------------------------

Picture this: You hand someone a dictionary and ask them to write poetry. They know every word, its spelling, its definition—but do they know how words dance together? How certain combinations evoke emotion while others fall flat? This is exactly what we're doing when we throw API documentation at our AI assistants and expect magic.

I've spent countless hours watching my AI coding assistant struggle with my own library, Crawl4AI. Despite feeding it comprehensive documentation, it would generate code that was _technically_ correct but practically useless. Like a tourist speaking from a phrasebook—grammatically sound, culturally tone-deaf.

Enter the Three-Dimensional Context Protocol
--------------------------------------------

What if, instead of dumping information, we provided _wisdom_? Not just the "what," but the "how" and "why"? This led me to develop what I call the **LLM Context Protocol**—a structured approach that mirrors how humans actually master libraries.

Think of it as HTTP for AI context. Just as HTTP doesn't dictate your website's content but provides a reliable structure for communication, this protocol doesn't prescribe _how_ you write your documentation—it provides a framework for _what_ your AI needs to truly understand your code.

### The Three Pillars of Library Wisdom

\#### 🧠 \*\*Memory: The Foundation\*\*

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-1) # AsyncWebCrawler.arun() - Memory Context [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-3) ## Signature [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-4) async def arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-5)     url: str, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-6)     config: CrawlerConfig = None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-7)     session_id: str = None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-8)     **kwargs [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-9) ) -> CrawlResult [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-11) ## Parameters [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-12) - url: Target URL to crawl [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-13) - config: Optional configuration object [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-14) - session_id: Optional session identifier for caching [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-0-15) ...`

This is your API reference—the facts, the parameters, the return types. It's the easiest part to generate and, ironically, the least useful in isolation. It's like memorizing a dictionary without understanding grammar.

\#### 🎯 \*\*Reasoning: The Soul\*\*

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-1) # AsyncWebCrawler Design Philosophy - Reasoning Context [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-3) ## Why Async-First Architecture? [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-5) Crawl4AI uses AsyncWebCrawler as its primary interface because modern web  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-6) scraping demands concurrency. Here's the thinking: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-8) 1. **Network I/O is slow**: Waiting synchronously wastes 90% of execution time [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-9) 2. **Modern sites are complex**: Multiple resources load in parallel [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-10) 3. **Scale matters**: You're rarely crawling just one page [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-11) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-12) ## When to Use Session Management [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-14) Session management isn't just about performance—it's about appearing human: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-15) - Use sessions when crawling multiple pages from the same domain [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-16) - Reuse browser contexts to maintain cookies and local storage [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-17) - But don't overdo it: too long sessions look suspicious [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-18) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-19) ## The Cache Strategy Decision Tree [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-20) if static_content and infrequent_updates: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-21)     use_cache_mode('read_write') [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-22) elif dynamic_content and real_time_needed: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-23)     use_cache_mode('bypass') [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-24) else: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-1-25)     use_cache_mode('read_only')  # Safe default`

This is where the library creator's philosophy lives. It's not just \*what\* the library does, but \*why\* it does it that way. This is the hardest part to write because it requires genuine understanding—and it's a red flag when a library lacks it.

\#### 💻 \*\*Examples: The Practice\*\*

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-1) # Crawling with JavaScript execution [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-2) result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-3)     url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-4)     js_code="window.scrollTo(0, document.body.scrollHeight);", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-5)     wait_for="css:.lazy-loaded-content" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-6) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-8) # Extracting structured data with CSS selectors [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-9) result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-10)     url="https://shop.example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-11)     extraction_strategy=CSSExtractionStrategy({ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-12)         "prices": "span.price::text", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-13)         "titles": "h2.product-title::text" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-14)     }) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-15) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-16) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-17) # Session-based crawling with custom headers [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-18) async with crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-19)     result1 = await crawler.arun(url1, session_id="product_scan") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/llm-context-revolution/#__codelineno-2-20)     result2 = await crawler.arun(url2, session_id="product_scan")`

Pure code. No fluff. Just patterns in action. Because sometimes, you just need to see how it's done.

Why This Matters (Especially for Smaller LLMs)
----------------------------------------------

Here's the thing about AI assistants: the smaller ones can't think their way out of a paper bag. They're like eager interns—full of potential but needing clear guidance. When you rely on a large language model to "figure it out" from raw API docs, you're asking it to reinvent your library's philosophy from scratch. Every. Single. Time.

By providing structured context across these three dimensions, we're not just documenting—we're teaching. We're transferring not just knowledge, but wisdom.

The Cultural DNA of Your Library
--------------------------------

🧬

**Your library's reasoning is its cultural DNA.**  
It reflects your taste, your architectural decisions, your opinions about how things should be done. A library without reasoning is like a recipe without techniques—sure, you have the ingredients, but good luck making something edible.

Think about it: When you learn a new library, what are you really after? You want mastery. And mastery comes from understanding: - **Memory** tells you what's possible - **Reasoning** tells you what's sensible - **Examples** show you what's practical

Together, they create wisdom.

Beyond Manual Documentation
---------------------------

Now, here's where it gets interesting. I didn't hand-craft thousands of lines of structured documentation for Crawl4AI. Who has that kind of time? Instead, I built a tool that:

1.  Analyzes your codebase
2.  Extracts API signatures and structures (Memory)
3.  Identifies patterns and architectural decisions (Reasoning)
4.  Collects real-world usage from tests and examples (Examples)
5.  Generates structured LLM context files

The beauty? This tool is becoming part of Crawl4AI itself. Because if we're going to revolutionize how AI understands our code, we might as well automate it.

The Protocol, Not the Prescription
----------------------------------

Remember: this is a protocol, not a prescription. Just as HTTP doesn't tell you what website to build, the LLM Context Protocol doesn't dictate your documentation style. It simply says:

> "If you want an AI to truly understand your library, it needs three things: facts, philosophy, and patterns."

How you deliver those is up to you. The protocol just ensures nothing important gets lost in translation.

Try It Yourself
---------------

Curious about implementing this for your own library? The context generation tool will be open-sourced as part of Crawl4AI. If you're interested in early access or want to discuss the approach, drop me a DM on X [@unclecode](https://twitter.com/unclecode)
.

Because let's face it: if we're going to live in a world where AI writes half our code, we might as well teach it properly.

* * *

A Final Thought
---------------

Memory + Reasoning + Examples = Wisdom

And wisdom, not information, is what makes great developers—human or artificial.

* * *

_Want to see this in action? Check out the [Crawl4AI LLM Context Builder](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/llmtxt/)
 and experience the difference structured context makes._

# Release Summary for Version 0.4.1 (December 8, 2024): Major Efficiency Boosts with New Features! - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Release Summary for Version 0.4.1 (December 8, 2024): Major Efficiency Boosts with New Features!
================================================================================================

_This post was generated with the help of ChatGPT, take everything with a grain of salt. 🧂_

Hi everyone,

I just finished putting together version 0.4.1 of Crawl4AI, and there are a few changes in here that I think you’ll find really helpful. I’ll explain what’s new, why it matters, and exactly how you can use these features (with the code to back it up). Let’s get into it.

* * *

### Handling Lazy Loading Better (Images Included)

One thing that always bugged me with crawlers is how often they miss lazy-loaded content, especially images. In this version, I made sure Crawl4AI **waits for all images to load** before moving forward. This is useful because many modern websites only load images when they’re in the viewport or after some JavaScript executes.

Here’s how to enable it:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-0-1) await crawler.crawl( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-0-2)     url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-0-3)     wait_for_images=True  # Add this argument to ensure images are fully loaded [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-0-4) )`

What this does is: 1. Waits for the page to reach a "network idle" state. 2. Ensures all images on the page have been completely loaded.

This single change handles the majority of lazy-loading cases you’re likely to encounter.

* * *

### Text-Only Mode (Fast, Lightweight Crawling)

Sometimes, you don’t need to download images or process JavaScript at all. For example, if you’re crawling to extract text data, you can enable **text-only mode** to speed things up. By disabling images, JavaScript, and other heavy resources, this mode makes crawling **3-4 times faster** in most cases.

Here’s how to turn it on:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-1-1) crawler = AsyncPlaywrightCrawlerStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-1-2)     text_mode=True  # Set this to True to enable text-only crawling [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-1-3) )`

When `text_mode=True`, the crawler automatically: - Disables GPU processing. - Blocks image and JavaScript resources. - Reduces the viewport size to 800x600 (you can override this with `viewport_width` and `viewport_height`).

If you need to crawl thousands of pages where you only care about text, this mode will save you a ton of time and resources.

* * *

### Adjusting the Viewport Dynamically

Another useful addition is the ability to **dynamically adjust the viewport size** to match the content on the page. This is particularly helpful when you’re working with responsive layouts or want to ensure all parts of the page load properly.

Here’s how it works: 1. The crawler calculates the page’s width and height after it loads. 2. It adjusts the viewport to fit the content dimensions. 3. (Optional) It uses Chrome DevTools Protocol (CDP) to simulate zooming out so everything fits in the viewport.

To enable this, use:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-2-1) await crawler.crawl( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-2-2)     url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-2-3)     adjust_viewport_to_content=True  # Dynamically adjusts the viewport [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-2-4) )`

This approach makes sure the entire page gets loaded into the viewport, especially for layouts that load content based on visibility.

* * *

### Simulating Full-Page Scrolling

Some websites load data dynamically as you scroll down the page. To handle these cases, I added support for **full-page scanning**. It simulates scrolling to the bottom of the page, checking for new content, and capturing it all.

Here’s an example:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-3-1) await crawler.crawl( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-3-2)     url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-3-3)     scan_full_page=True,   # Enables scrolling [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-3-4)     scroll_delay=0.2       # Waits 200ms between scrolls (optional) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-3-5) )`

What happens here: 1. The crawler scrolls down in increments, waiting for content to load after each scroll. 2. It stops when no new content appears (i.e., dynamic elements stop loading). 3. It scrolls back to the top before finishing (if necessary).

If you’ve ever had to deal with infinite scroll pages, this is going to save you a lot of headaches.

* * *

### Reusing Browser Sessions (Save Time on Setup)

By default, every time you crawl a page, a new browser context (or tab) is created. That’s fine for small crawls, but if you’re working on a large dataset, it’s more efficient to reuse the same session.

I added a method called `create_session` for this:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-1) session_id = await crawler.create_session() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-3) # Use the same session for multiple crawls [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-4) await crawler.crawl( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-5)     url="https://example.com/page1", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-6)     session_id=session_id  # Reuse the session [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-7) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-8) await crawler.crawl( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-9)     url="https://example.com/page2", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-10)     session_id=session_id [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-4-11) )`

This avoids creating a new tab for every page, speeding up the crawl and reducing memory usage.

* * *

### Other Updates

Here are a few smaller updates I’ve made: - **Light Mode**: Use `light_mode=True` to disable background processes, extensions, and other unnecessary features, making the browser more efficient. - **Logging**: Improved logs to make debugging easier. - **Defaults**: Added sensible defaults for things like `delay_before_return_html` (now set to 0.1 seconds).

* * *

### How to Get the Update

You can install or upgrade to version `0.4.1` like this:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.1/#__codelineno-5-1) pip install crawl4ai --upgrade`

As always, I’d love to hear your thoughts. If there’s something you think could be improved or if you have suggestions for future versions, let me know!

Enjoy the new features, and happy crawling! 🕷️

* * *

* * *

# 0.4.2 - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

🚀 Crawl4AI 0.4.2 Update: Smarter Crawling Just Got Easier (Dec 12, 2024)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

### Hey Developers,

I’m excited to share Crawl4AI 0.4.2—a major upgrade that makes crawling smarter, faster, and a whole lot more intuitive. I’ve packed in a bunch of new features to simplify your workflows and improve your experience. Let’s cut to the chase!

* * *

### 🔧 **Configurable Browser and Crawler Behavior**

You’ve asked for better control over how browsers and crawlers are configured, and now you’ve got it. With the new `BrowserConfig` and `CrawlerRunConfig` objects, you can set up your browser and crawling behavior exactly how you want. No more cluttering `arun` with a dozen arguments—just pass in your configs and go.

**Example:**

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-0-1) from crawl4ai import BrowserConfig, CrawlerRunConfig, AsyncWebCrawler [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-0-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-0-3) browser_config = BrowserConfig(headless=True, viewport_width=1920, viewport_height=1080) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-0-4) crawler_config = CrawlerRunConfig(cache_mode="BYPASS") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-0-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-0-6) async with AsyncWebCrawler(config=browser_config) as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-0-7)     result = await crawler.arun(url="https://example.com", config=crawler_config) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-0-8)     print(result.markdown[:500])`

This setup is a game-changer for scalability, keeping your code clean and flexible as we add more parameters in the future.

Remember: If you like to use the old way, you can still pass arguments directly to `arun` as before, no worries!

* * *

### 🔐 **Streamlined Session Management**

Here’s the big one: You can now pass local storage and cookies directly. Whether it’s setting values programmatically or importing a saved JSON state, managing sessions has never been easier. This is a must-have for authenticated crawls—just export your storage state once and reuse it effortlessly across runs.

**Example:** 1. Open a browser, log in manually, and export the storage state. 2. Import the JSON file for seamless authenticated crawling:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-1-1) result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-1-2)     url="https://example.com/protected", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-1-3)     storage_state="my_storage_state.json" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.4.2/#__codelineno-1-4) )`

* * *

### 🔢 **Handling Large Pages: Supercharged Screenshots and PDF Conversion**

Two big upgrades here:

*   **Blazing-fast long-page screenshots**: Turn extremely long web pages into clean, high-quality screenshots—without breaking a sweat. It’s optimized to handle large content without lag.
    
*   **Full-page PDF exports**: Now, you can also convert any page into a PDF with all the details intact. Perfect for archiving or sharing complex layouts.
    

* * *

### 🔧 **Other Cool Stuff**

*   **Anti-bot enhancements**: Magic mode now handles overlays, user simulation, and anti-detection features like a pro.
*   **JavaScript execution**: Execute custom JS snippets to handle dynamic content. No more wrestling with endless page interactions.

* * *

### 📊 **Performance Boosts and Dev-friendly Updates**

*   Faster rendering and viewport adjustments for better performance.
*   Improved cookie and local storage handling for seamless authentication.
*   Better debugging with detailed logs and actionable error messages.

* * *

### 🔠 **Use Cases You’ll Love**

1. **Authenticated Crawls**: Login once, export your storage state, and reuse it across multiple requests without the headache. 2. **Long-page Screenshots**: Perfect for blogs, e-commerce pages, or any endless-scroll website. 3. **PDF Export**: Create professional-looking page PDFs in seconds.

* * *

### Let’s Get Crawling

Crawl4AI 0.4.2 is ready for you to download and try. I’m always looking for ways to improve, so don’t hold back—share your thoughts and feedback.

Happy Crawling! 🚀

# Cache Modes - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Crawl4AI Cache System and Migration Guide
=========================================

Overview
--------

Starting from version 0.5.0, Crawl4AI introduces a new caching system that replaces the old boolean flags with a more intuitive `CacheMode` enum. This change simplifies cache control and makes the behavior more predictable.

Old vs New Approach
-------------------

### Old Way (Deprecated)

The old system used multiple boolean flags: - `bypass_cache`: Skip cache entirely - `disable_cache`: Disable all caching - `no_cache_read`: Don't read from cache - `no_cache_write`: Don't write to cache

### New Way (Recommended)

The new system uses a single `CacheMode` enum: - `CacheMode.ENABLED`: Normal caching (read/write) - `CacheMode.DISABLED`: No caching at all - `CacheMode.READ_ONLY`: Only read from cache - `CacheMode.WRITE_ONLY`: Only write to cache - `CacheMode.BYPASS`: Skip cache for this operation

Migration Example
-----------------

### Old Code (Deprecated)

# Browser, Crawler & LLM Config - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Browser, Crawler & LLM Configuration (Quick Overview)
=====================================================

Crawl4AI's flexibility stems from two key classes:

1.  **`BrowserConfig`** – Dictates **how** the browser is launched and behaves (e.g., headless or visible, proxy, user agent).
2.  **`CrawlerRunConfig`** – Dictates **how** each **crawl** operates (e.g., caching, extraction, timeouts, JavaScript code to run, etc.).
3.  **`LLMConfig`** - Dictates **how** LLM providers are configured. (model, api token, base url, temperature etc.)

In most examples, you create **one** `BrowserConfig` for the entire crawler session, then pass a **fresh** or re-used `CrawlerRunConfig` whenever you call `arun()`. This tutorial shows the most commonly used parameters. If you need advanced or rarely used fields, see the [Configuration Parameters](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/parameters/)
.

* * *

1\. BrowserConfig Essentials
----------------------------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-1) class BrowserConfig: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-2)     def __init__( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-3)         browser_type="chromium", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-4)         headless=True, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-5)         proxy_config=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-6)         viewport_width=1080, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-7)         viewport_height=600, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-8)         verbose=True, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-9)         use_persistent_context=False, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-10)         user_data_dir=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-11)         cookies=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-12)         headers=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-13)         user_agent=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-14)         text_mode=False, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-15)         light_mode=False, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-16)         extra_args=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-17)         # ... other advanced parameters omitted here [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-18)     ): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-0-19)         ...`

### Key Fields to Note

1.  **`browser_type`**
2.  Options: `"chromium"`, `"firefox"`, or `"webkit"`.
3.  Defaults to `"chromium"`.
4.  If you need a different engine, specify it here.
    
5.  **`headless`**
    
6.  `True`: Runs the browser in headless mode (invisible browser).
7.  `False`: Runs the browser in visible mode, which helps with debugging.
    
8.  **`proxy_config`**
    
9.  A dictionary with fields like:  
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-1-1) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-1-2)     "server": "http://proxy.example.com:8080",  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-1-3)     "username": "...",  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-1-4)     "password": "..." [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-1-5) }`
    
10.  Leave as `None` if a proxy is not required.
    
11.  **`viewport_width` & `viewport_height`**:
    
12.  The initial window size.
13.  Some sites behave differently with smaller or bigger viewports.
    
14.  **`verbose`**:
    
15.  If `True`, prints extra logs.
16.  Handy for debugging.
    
17.  **`use_persistent_context`**:
    
18.  If `True`, uses a **persistent** browser profile, storing cookies/local storage across runs.
19.  Typically also set `user_data_dir` to point to a folder.
    
20.  **`cookies`** & **`headers`**:
    
21.  If you want to start with specific cookies or add universal HTTP headers, set them here.
22.  E.g. `cookies=[{"name": "session", "value": "abc123", "domain": "example.com"}]`.
    
23.  **`user_agent`**:
    
24.  Custom User-Agent string. If `None`, a default is used.
25.  You can also set `user_agent_mode="random"` for randomization (if you want to fight bot detection).
    
26.  **`text_mode`** & **`light_mode`**:
    
27.  `text_mode=True` disables images, possibly speeding up text-only crawls.
28.  `light_mode=True` turns off certain background features for performance.
    
29.  **`extra_args`**:
    
    *   Additional flags for the underlying browser.
    *   E.g. `["--disable-extensions"]`.

### Helper Methods

Both configuration classes provide a `clone()` method to create modified copies:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-1) # Create a base browser config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-2) base_browser = BrowserConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-3)     browser_type="chromium", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-4)     headless=True, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-5)     text_mode=True [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-6) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-8) # Create a visible browser config for debugging [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-9) debug_browser = base_browser.clone( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-10)     headless=False, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-11)     verbose=True [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-2-12) )`

**Minimal Example**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-1) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, BrowserConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-3) browser_conf = BrowserConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-4)     browser_type="firefox", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-5)     headless=False, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-6)     text_mode=True [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-7) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-9) async with AsyncWebCrawler(config=browser_conf) as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-10)     result = await crawler.arun("https://example.com") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-3-11)     print(result.markdown[:300])`

* * *

2\. CrawlerRunConfig Essentials
-------------------------------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-1) class CrawlerRunConfig: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-2)     def __init__( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-3)         word_count_threshold=200, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-4)         extraction_strategy=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-5)         markdown_generator=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-6)         cache_mode=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-7)         js_code=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-8)         wait_for=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-9)         screenshot=False, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-10)         pdf=False, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-11)         capture_mhtml=False, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-12)         # Location and Identity Parameters [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-13)         locale=None,            # e.g. "en-US", "fr-FR" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-14)         timezone_id=None,       # e.g. "America/New_York" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-15)         geolocation=None,       # GeolocationConfig object [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-16)         # Resource Management [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-17)         enable_rate_limiting=False, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-18)         rate_limit_config=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-19)         memory_threshold_percent=70.0, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-20)         check_interval=1.0, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-21)         max_session_permit=20, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-22)         display_mode=None, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-23)         verbose=True, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-24)         stream=False,  # Enable streaming for arun_many() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-25)         # ... other advanced parameters omitted [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-26)     ): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-4-27)         ...`

### Key Fields to Note

1.  **`word_count_threshold`**:
2.  The minimum word count before a block is considered.
3.  If your site has lots of short paragraphs or items, you can lower it.
    
4.  **`extraction_strategy`**:
    
5.  Where you plug in JSON-based extraction (CSS, LLM, etc.).
6.  If `None`, no structured extraction is done (only raw/cleaned HTML + markdown).
    
7.  **`markdown_generator`**:
    
8.  E.g., `DefaultMarkdownGenerator(...)`, controlling how HTML→Markdown conversion is done.
9.  If `None`, a default approach is used.
    
10.  **`cache_mode`**:
    
11.  Controls caching behavior (`ENABLED`, `BYPASS`, `DISABLED`, etc.).
12.  If `None`, defaults to some level of caching or you can specify `CacheMode.ENABLED`.
    
13.  **`js_code`**:
    
14.  A string or list of JS strings to execute.
15.  Great for "Load More" buttons or user interactions.
    
16.  **`wait_for`**:
    
17.  A CSS or JS expression to wait for before extracting content.
18.  Common usage: `wait_for="css:.main-loaded"` or `wait_for="js:() => window.loaded === true"`.
    
19.  **`screenshot`**, **`pdf`**, & **`capture_mhtml`**:
    
20.  If `True`, captures a screenshot, PDF, or MHTML snapshot after the page is fully loaded.
21.  The results go to `result.screenshot` (base64), `result.pdf` (bytes), or `result.mhtml` (string).
    
22.  **Location Parameters**:
    
23.  **`locale`**: Browser's locale (e.g., `"en-US"`, `"fr-FR"`) for language preferences
24.  **`timezone_id`**: Browser's timezone (e.g., `"America/New_York"`, `"Europe/Paris"`)
25.  **`geolocation`**: GPS coordinates via `GeolocationConfig(latitude=48.8566, longitude=2.3522)`
26.  See [Identity Based Crawling](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/identity-based-crawling/#7-locale-timezone-and-geolocation-control)
    
27.  **`verbose`**:
    
28.  Logs additional runtime details.
29.  Overlaps with the browser's verbosity if also set to `True` in `BrowserConfig`.
    
30.  **`enable_rate_limiting`**:
    
31.  If `True`, enables rate limiting for batch processing.
32.  Requires `rate_limit_config` to be set.
    
33.  **`memory_threshold_percent`**:
    
    *   The memory threshold (as a percentage) to monitor.
    *   If exceeded, the crawler will pause or slow down.
34.  **`check_interval`**:
    
    *   The interval (in seconds) to check system resources.
    *   Affects how often memory and CPU usage are monitored.
35.  **`max_session_permit`**:
    
    *   The maximum number of concurrent crawl sessions.
    *   Helps prevent overwhelming the system.
36.  **`display_mode`**:
    
    *   The display mode for progress information (`DETAILED`, `BRIEF`, etc.).
    *   Affects how much information is printed during the crawl.

### Helper Methods

The `clone()` method is particularly useful for creating variations of your crawler configuration:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-1) # Create a base configuration [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-2) base_config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-3)     cache_mode=CacheMode.ENABLED, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-4)     word_count_threshold=200, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-5)     wait_until="networkidle" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-6) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-8) # Create variations for different use cases [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-9) stream_config = base_config.clone( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-10)     stream=True,  # Enable streaming mode [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-11)     cache_mode=CacheMode.BYPASS [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-12) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-14) debug_config = base_config.clone( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-15)     page_timeout=120000,  # Longer timeout for debugging [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-16)     verbose=True [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-5-17) )`

The `clone()` method: - Creates a new instance with all the same settings - Updates only the specified parameters - Leaves the original configuration unchanged - Perfect for creating variations without repeating all parameters

* * *

3\. LLMConfig Essentials
------------------------

### Key fields to note

1.  **`provider`**:
2.  Which LLM provider to use.
3.  Possible values are `"ollama/llama3","groq/llama3-70b-8192","groq/llama3-8b-8192", "openai/gpt-4o-mini" ,"openai/gpt-4o","openai/o1-mini","openai/o1-preview","openai/o3-mini","openai/o3-mini-high","anthropic/claude-3-haiku-20240307","anthropic/claude-3-opus-20240229","anthropic/claude-3-sonnet-20240229","anthropic/claude-3-5-sonnet-20240620","gemini/gemini-pro","gemini/gemini-1.5-pro","gemini/gemini-2.0-flash","gemini/gemini-2.0-flash-exp","gemini/gemini-2.0-flash-lite-preview-02-05","deepseek/deepseek-chat"`  
    _(default: `"openai/gpt-4o-mini"`)_
    
4.  **`api_token`**:
    
    *   Optional. When not provided explicitly, api\_token will be read from environment variables based on provider. For example: If a gemini model is passed as provider then,`"GEMINI_API_KEY"` will be read from environment variables
    *   API token of LLM provider  
        eg: `api_token = "gsk_1ClHGGJ7Lpn4WGybR7vNWGdyb3FY7zXEw3SCiy0BAVM9lL8CQv"`
    *   Environment variable - use with prefix "env:"  
        eg:`api_token = "env: GROQ_API_KEY"`
5.  **`base_url`**:
    
6.  If your provider has a custom endpoint

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-6-1) llm_config = LLMConfig(provider="openai/gpt-4o-mini", api_token=os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY"))`

4\. Putting It All Together
---------------------------

In a typical scenario, you define **one** `BrowserConfig` for your crawler session, then create **one or more** `CrawlerRunConfig` & `LLMConfig` depending on each call's needs:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-2) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, BrowserConfig, CrawlerRunConfig, CacheMode, LLMConfig, LLMContentFilter, DefaultMarkdownGenerator [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-3) from crawl4ai import JsonCssExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-5) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-6)     # 2) Example extraction strategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-14)     schema = { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-15)         "name": "Articles", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-16)         "baseSelector": "div.article", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-17)         "fields": [ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-18)             {"name": "title", "selector": "h2", "type": "text"}, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-19)             {"name": "link", "selector": "a", "type": "attribute", "attribute": "href"} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-20)         ] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-21)     } [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-22)     extraction = JsonCssExtractionStrategy(schema) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-23) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-24)     # 3) Example LLM content filtering [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-25) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-26)     gemini_config = LLMConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-27)         provider="gemini/gemini-1.5-pro",  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-28)         api_token = "env:GEMINI_API_TOKEN" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-29)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-30) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-31)     # Initialize LLM filter with specific instruction [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-32)     filter = LLMContentFilter( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-33)         llm_config=gemini_config,  # Adjust based on your needs [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-47)         verbose=True [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-48)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-49) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-50)     md_generator = DefaultMarkdownGenerator( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-51)         content_filter=filter, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-52)         options={"ignore_links": True} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-53)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-54) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-55)     # 4) Crawler run config: skip cache, use extraction [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-56)     run_conf = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-57)         markdown_generator=md_generator, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-58)         extraction_strategy=extraction, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-59)         cache_mode=CacheMode.BYPASS, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-60)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-61) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-62)     async with AsyncWebCrawler(config=browser_conf) as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-63)         # 4) Execute the crawl [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-64)         result = await crawler.arun(url="https://example.com/news", config=run_conf) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-65) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-66)         if result.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-67)             print("Extracted content:", result.extracted_content) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-68)         else: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-69)             print("Error:", result.error_message) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-70) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-71) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/browser-crawler-config/#__codelineno-7-72)     asyncio.run(main())`

* * *

5\. Next Steps
--------------

For a **detailed list** of available parameters (including advanced ones), see:

*   [BrowserConfig, CrawlerRunConfig & LLMConfig Reference](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/parameters/)
    

You can explore topics like:

*   **Custom Hooks & Auth** (Inject JavaScript or handle login forms).
*   **Session Management** (Re-use pages, preserve state across multiple calls).
*   **Magic Mode** or **Identity-based Crawling** (Fight bot detection by simulating user behavior).
*   **Advanced Caching** (Fine-tune read/write cache modes).

* * *

6\. Conclusion
--------------

**BrowserConfig**, **CrawlerRunConfig** and **LLMConfig** give you straightforward ways to define:

*   **Which** browser to launch, how it should run, and any proxy or user agent needs.
*   **How** each crawl should behave—caching, timeouts, JavaScript code, extraction strategies, etc.
*   **Which** LLM provider to use, api token, temperature and base url for custom endpoints

Use them together for **clear, maintainable** code, and when you need more specialized behavior, check out the advanced parameters in the [reference docs](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/parameters/)
. Happy crawling!

* * *

\> Feedback
