# Fit Markdown - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Fit Markdown with Pruning & BM25
================================

**Fit Markdown** is a specialized **filtered** version of your page’s markdown, focusing on the most relevant content. By default, Crawl4AI converts the entire HTML into a broad **raw\_markdown**. With fit markdown, we apply a **content filter** algorithm (e.g., **Pruning** or **BM25**) to remove or rank low-value sections—such as repetitive sidebars, shallow text blocks, or irrelevancies—leaving a concise textual “core.”

* * *

1\. How “Fit Markdown” Works
----------------------------

### 1.1 The `content_filter`

In **`CrawlerRunConfig`**, you can specify a **`content_filter`** to shape how content is pruned or ranked before final markdown generation. A filter’s logic is applied **before** or **during** the HTML→Markdown process, producing:

*   **`result.markdown.raw_markdown`** (unfiltered)
*   **`result.markdown.fit_markdown`** (filtered or “fit” version)
*   **`result.markdown.fit_html`** (the corresponding HTML snippet that produced `fit_markdown`)

### 1.2 Common Filters

1. **PruningContentFilter** – Scores each node by text density, link density, and tag importance, discarding those below a threshold.  
2. **BM25ContentFilter** – Focuses on textual relevance using BM25 ranking, especially useful if you have a specific user query (e.g., “machine learning” or “food nutrition”).

* * *

2\. PruningContentFilter
------------------------

**Pruning** discards less relevant nodes based on **text density, link density, and tag importance**. It’s a heuristic-based approach—if certain sections appear too “thin” or too “spammy,” they’re pruned.

### 2.1 Usage Example

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-2) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-3) from crawl4ai.content_filter_strategy import PruningContentFilter [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-4) from crawl4ai.markdown_generation_strategy import DefaultMarkdownGenerator [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-6) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-7)     # Step 1: Create a pruning filter [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-8)     prune_filter = PruningContentFilter( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-9)         # Lower → more content retained, higher → more content pruned [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-10)         threshold=0.45,            [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-11)         # "fixed" or "dynamic" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-12)         threshold_type="dynamic",   [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-13)         # Ignore nodes with <5 words [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-14)         min_word_threshold=5       [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-15)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-16) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-17)     # Step 2: Insert it into a Markdown Generator [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-18)     md_generator = DefaultMarkdownGenerator(content_filter=prune_filter) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-19) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-20)     # Step 3: Pass it to CrawlerRunConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-21)     config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-22)         markdown_generator=md_generator [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-23)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-24) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-25)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-26)         result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-27)             url="https://news.ycombinator.com",  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-28)             config=config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-29)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-30) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-31)         if result.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-32)             # 'fit_markdown' is your pruned content, focusing on "denser" text [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-33)             print("Raw Markdown length:", len(result.markdown.raw_markdown)) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-34)             print("Fit Markdown length:", len(result.markdown.fit_markdown)) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-35)         else: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-36)             print("Error:", result.error_message) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-37) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-38) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-0-39)     asyncio.run(main())`

### 2.2 Key Parameters

*   **`min_word_threshold`** (int): If a block has fewer words than this, it’s pruned.
*   **`threshold_type`** (str):
*   `"fixed"` → each node must exceed `threshold` (0–1).
*   `"dynamic"` → node scoring adjusts according to tag type, text/link density, etc.
*   **`threshold`** (float, default ~0.48): The base or “anchor” cutoff.

**Algorithmic Factors**:

*   **Text density** – Encourages blocks that have a higher ratio of text to overall content.
*   **Link density** – Penalizes sections that are mostly links.
*   **Tag importance** – e.g., an `<article>` or `<p>` might be more important than a `<div>`.
*   **Structural context** – If a node is deeply nested or in a suspected sidebar, it might be deprioritized.

* * *

3\. BM25ContentFilter
---------------------

**BM25** is a classical text ranking algorithm often used in search engines. If you have a **user query** or rely on page metadata to derive a query, BM25 can identify which text chunks best match that query.

### 3.1 Usage Example

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-2) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-3) from crawl4ai.content_filter_strategy import BM25ContentFilter [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-4) from crawl4ai.markdown_generation_strategy import DefaultMarkdownGenerator [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-6) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-7)     # 1) A BM25 filter with a user query [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-8)     bm25_filter = BM25ContentFilter( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-9)         user_query="startup fundraising tips", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-10)         # Adjust for stricter or looser results [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-11)         bm25_threshold=1.2   [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-12)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-14)     # 2) Insert into a Markdown Generator [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-15)     md_generator = DefaultMarkdownGenerator(content_filter=bm25_filter) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-16) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-17)     # 3) Pass to crawler config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-18)     config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-19)         markdown_generator=md_generator [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-20)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-21) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-22)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-23)         result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-24)             url="https://news.ycombinator.com",  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-25)             config=config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-26)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-27)         if result.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-28)             print("Fit Markdown (BM25 query-based):") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-29)             print(result.markdown.fit_markdown) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-30)         else: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-31)             print("Error:", result.error_message) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-32) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-33) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-1-34)     asyncio.run(main())`

### 3.2 Parameters

*   **`user_query`** (str, optional): E.g. `"machine learning"`. If blank, the filter tries to glean a query from page metadata.
*   **`bm25_threshold`** (float, default 1.0):
*   Higher → fewer chunks but more relevant.
*   Lower → more inclusive.

> In more advanced scenarios, you might see parameters like `language`, `case_sensitive`, or `priority_tags` to refine how text is tokenized or weighted.

* * *

4\. Accessing the “Fit” Output
------------------------------

After the crawl, your “fit” content is found in **`result.markdown.fit_markdown`**.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-2-1) fit_md = result.markdown.fit_markdown [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-2-2) fit_html = result.markdown.fit_html`

If the content filter is **BM25**, you might see additional logic or references in `fit_markdown` that highlight relevant segments. If it’s **Pruning**, the text is typically well-cleaned but not necessarily matched to a query.

* * *

5\. Code Patterns Recap
-----------------------

### 5.1 Pruning

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-3-1) prune_filter = PruningContentFilter( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-3-2)     threshold=0.5, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-3-3)     threshold_type="fixed", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-3-4)     min_word_threshold=10 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-3-5) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-3-6) md_generator = DefaultMarkdownGenerator(content_filter=prune_filter) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-3-7) config = CrawlerRunConfig(markdown_generator=md_generator)`

### 5.2 BM25

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-4-1) bm25_filter = BM25ContentFilter( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-4-2)     user_query="health benefits fruit", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-4-3)     bm25_threshold=1.2 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-4-4) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-4-5) md_generator = DefaultMarkdownGenerator(content_filter=bm25_filter) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-4-6) config = CrawlerRunConfig(markdown_generator=md_generator)`

* * *

6\. Combining with “word\_count\_threshold” & Exclusions
--------------------------------------------------------

Remember you can also specify:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-5-1) config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-5-2)     word_count_threshold=10, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-5-3)     excluded_tags=["nav", "footer", "header"], [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-5-4)     exclude_external_links=True, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-5-5)     markdown_generator=DefaultMarkdownGenerator( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-5-6)         content_filter=PruningContentFilter(threshold=0.5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-5-7)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-5-8) )`

Thus, **multi-level** filtering occurs:

1.  The crawler’s `excluded_tags` are removed from the HTML first.
2.  The content filter (Pruning, BM25, or custom) prunes or ranks the remaining text blocks.
3.  The final “fit” content is generated in `result.markdown.fit_markdown`.

* * *

7\. Custom Filters
------------------

If you need a different approach (like a specialized ML model or site-specific heuristics), you can create a new class inheriting from `RelevantContentFilter` and implement `filter_content(html)`. Then inject it into your **markdown generator**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-6-1) from crawl4ai.content_filter_strategy import RelevantContentFilter [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-6-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-6-3) class MyCustomFilter(RelevantContentFilter): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-6-4)     def filter_content(self, html, min_word_threshold=None): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-6-5)         # parse HTML, implement custom logic [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/fit-markdown/#__codelineno-6-6)         return [block for block in ... if ... some condition...]`

**Steps**:

1.  Subclass `RelevantContentFilter`.
2.  Implement `filter_content(...)`.
3.  Use it in your `DefaultMarkdownGenerator(content_filter=MyCustomFilter(...))`.

* * *

8\. Final Thoughts
------------------

**Fit Markdown** is a crucial feature for:

*   **Summaries**: Quickly get the important text from a cluttered page.
*   **Search**: Combine with **BM25** to produce content relevant to a query.
*   **AI Pipelines**: Filter out boilerplate so LLM-based extraction or summarization runs on denser text.

**Key Points**: - **PruningContentFilter**: Great if you just want the “meatiest” text without a user query.  
\- **BM25ContentFilter**: Perfect for query-based extraction or searching.  
\- Combine with **`excluded_tags`, `exclude_external_links`, `word_count_threshold`** to refine your final “fit” text.  
\- Fit markdown ends up in **`result.markdown.fit_markdown`**; eventually **`result.markdown.fit_markdown`** in future versions.

With these tools, you can **zero in** on the text that truly matters, ignoring spammy or boilerplate content, and produce a concise, relevant “fit markdown” for your AI or data pipelines. Happy pruning and searching!

*   Last Updated: 2025-01-01

* * *

# Crawl4AI 0.4.3: Major Performance Boost & LLM Integration - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Crawl4AI 0.4.3: Major Performance Boost & LLM Integration
=========================================================

We're excited to announce Crawl4AI 0.4.3, focusing on three key areas: Speed & Efficiency, LLM Integration, and Core Platform Improvements. This release significantly improves crawling performance while adding powerful new LLM-powered features.

⚡ Speed & Efficiency Improvements
---------------------------------

### 1\. Memory-Adaptive Dispatcher System

The new dispatcher system provides intelligent resource management and real-time monitoring:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-1) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig, DisplayMode [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-2) from crawl4ai.async_dispatcher import MemoryAdaptiveDispatcher, CrawlerMonitor [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-4) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-5)     urls = ["https://example1.com", "https://example2.com"] * 50 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-7)     # Configure memory-aware dispatch [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-8)     dispatcher = MemoryAdaptiveDispatcher( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-9)         memory_threshold_percent=80.0,  # Auto-throttle at 80% memory [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-10)         check_interval=0.5,             # Check every 0.5 seconds [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-11)         max_session_permit=20,          # Max concurrent sessions [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-12)         monitor=CrawlerMonitor(         # Real-time monitoring [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-13)             display_mode=DisplayMode.DETAILED [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-14)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-15)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-16) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-17)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-18)         results = await dispatcher.run_urls( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-19)             urls=urls, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-20)             crawler=crawler, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-21)             config=CrawlerRunConfig() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-0-22)         )`

### 2\. Streaming Support

Process crawled URLs in real-time instead of waiting for all results:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-1-1) config = CrawlerRunConfig(stream=True) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-1-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-1-3) async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-1-4)     async for result in await crawler.arun_many(urls, config=config): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-1-5)         print(f"Got result for {result.url}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-1-6)         # Process each result immediately`

### 3\. LXML-Based Scraping

New LXML scraping strategy offering up to 20x faster parsing:

🤖 LLM Integration
------------------

### 1\. LLM-Powered Markdown Generation

Smart content filtering and organization using LLMs:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-3-1) config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-3-2)     markdown_generator=DefaultMarkdownGenerator( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-3-3)         content_filter=LLMContentFilter( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-3-4)             provider="openai/gpt-4o", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-3-5)             instruction="Extract technical documentation and code examples" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-3-6)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-3-7)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-3-8) )`

🔧 Core Improvements
--------------------

### 1\. Proxy Support & Rotation

Integrated proxy support with automatic rotation and verification:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-5-1) config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-5-2)     proxy_config={ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-5-3)         "server": "http://proxy:8080", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-5-4)         "username": "user", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-5-5)         "password": "pass" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-5-6)     } [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-5-7) )`

### 2\. Robots.txt Compliance

Built-in robots.txt support with SQLite caching:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-6-1) config = CrawlerRunConfig(check_robots_txt=True) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-6-2) result = await crawler.arun(url, config=config) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-6-3) if result.status_code == 403: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-6-4)     print("Access blocked by robots.txt")`

### 3\. URL Redirection Tracking

Track final URLs after redirects:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-7-1) result = await crawler.arun(url) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-7-2) print(f"Initial URL: {url}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-7-3) print(f"Final URL: {result.redirected_url}")`

Performance Impact
------------------

*   Memory usage reduced by up to 40% with adaptive dispatcher
*   Parsing speed increased up to 20x with LXML strategy
*   Streaming reduces memory footprint for large crawls by ~60%

Getting Started
---------------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/v0.4.3b1/#__codelineno-8-1) pip install -U crawl4ai`

For complete examples, check our [demo repository](https://github.com/unclecode/crawl4ai/examples)
.

# Crawl4AI v0.5.0 Release Notes - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Crawl4AI v0.5.0 Release Notes
=============================

**Release Theme: Power, Flexibility, and Scalability**

Crawl4AI v0.5.0 is a major release focused on significantly enhancing the library's power, flexibility, and scalability. Key improvements include a new **deep crawling** system, a **memory-adaptive dispatcher** for handling large-scale crawls, **multiple crawling strategies** (including a fast HTTP-only crawler), **Docker** deployment options, and a powerful **command-line interface (CLI)**. This release also includes numerous bug fixes, performance optimizations, and documentation updates.

**Important Note:** This release contains several **breaking changes**. Please review the "Breaking Changes" section carefully and update your code accordingly.

Key Features
------------

### 1\. Deep Crawling

Crawl4AI now supports deep crawling, allowing you to explore websites beyond the initial URLs. This is controlled by the `deep_crawl_strategy` parameter in `CrawlerRunConfig`. Several strategies are available:

*   **`BFSDeepCrawlStrategy` (Breadth-First Search):** Explores the website level by level. (Default)
*   **`DFSDeepCrawlStrategy` (Depth-First Search):** Explores each branch as deeply as possible before backtracking.
*   **`BestFirstCrawlingStrategy`:** Uses a scoring function to prioritize which URLs to crawl next.

### 2\. Memory-Adaptive Dispatcher

The new `MemoryAdaptiveDispatcher` dynamically adjusts concurrency based on available system memory and includes built-in rate limiting. This prevents out-of-memory errors and avoids overwhelming target websites.

**Breaking Change:** `AsyncWebCrawler.arun_many()` now uses `MemoryAdaptiveDispatcher` by default. Existing code that relied on unbounded concurrency may require adjustments.

### 3\. Multiple Crawling Strategies (Playwright and HTTP)

Crawl4AI now offers two crawling strategies:

*   **`AsyncPlaywrightCrawlerStrategy` (Default):** Uses Playwright for browser-based crawling, supporting JavaScript rendering and complex interactions.
*   **`AsyncHTTPCrawlerStrategy`:** A lightweight, fast, and memory-efficient HTTP-only crawler. Ideal for simple scraping tasks where browser rendering is unnecessary.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-1) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig, HTTPCrawlerConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-2) from crawl4ai.async_crawler_strategy import AsyncHTTPCrawlerStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-3) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-5) # Use the HTTP crawler strategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-6) http_crawler_config = HTTPCrawlerConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-7)         method="GET", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-8)         headers={"User-Agent": "MyCustomBot/1.0"}, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-9)         follow_redirects=True, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-10)         verify_ssl=True [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-11) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-12) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-13) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-14)     async with AsyncWebCrawler(crawler_strategy=AsyncHTTPCrawlerStrategy(browser_config =http_crawler_config)) as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-15)         result = await crawler.arun("https://example.com") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-16)         print(f"Status code: {result.status_code}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-17)         print(f"Content length: {len(result.html)}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-18) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-2-19) asyncio.run(main())`

### 4\. Docker Deployment

Crawl4AI can now be easily deployed as a Docker container, providing a consistent and isolated environment. The Docker image includes a FastAPI server with both streaming and non-streaming endpoints.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-3-1) # Build the image (from the project root) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-3-2) docker build -t crawl4ai . [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-3-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-3-4) # Run the container [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-3-5) docker run -d -p 8000:8000 --name crawl4ai crawl4ai`

**API Endpoints:**

*   `/crawl` (POST): Non-streaming crawl.
*   `/crawl/stream` (POST): Streaming crawl (NDJSON).
*   `/health` (GET): Health check.
*   `/schema` (GET): Returns configuration schemas.
*   `/md/{url}` (GET): Returns markdown content of the URL.
*   `/llm/{url}` (GET): Returns LLM extracted content.
*   `/token` (POST): Get JWT token

**Breaking Changes:**

*   Docker deployment now requires a `.llm.env` file for API keys.
*   Docker deployment now requires Redis and a new `config.yml` structure.
*   Server startup now uses `supervisord` instead of direct process management.
*   Docker server now requires authentication by default (JWT tokens).

See the [Docker deployment documentation](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/)
 for detailed instructions.

### 5\. Command-Line Interface (CLI)

A new CLI (`crwl`) provides convenient access to Crawl4AI's functionality from the terminal.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-1) # Basic crawl [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-2) crwl https://example.com [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-4) # Get markdown output [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-5) crwl https://example.com -o markdown [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-7) # Use a configuration file [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-8) crwl https://example.com -B browser.yml -C crawler.yml [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-9) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-10) # Use LLM-based extraction [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-11) crwl https://example.com -e extract.yml -s schema.json [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-12) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-13) # Ask a question about the crawled content [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-14) crwl https://example.com -q "What is the main topic?" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-15) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-16) # See usage examples [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-4-17) crwl --example`

See the [CLI documentation](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/docs/md_v2/core/cli.md)
 for more details.

### 6\. LXML Scraping Mode

Added `LXMLWebScrapingStrategy` for faster HTML parsing using the `lxml` library. This can significantly improve scraping performance, especially for large or complex pages. Set `scraping_strategy=LXMLWebScrapingStrategy()` in your `CrawlerRunConfig`.

**Breaking Change:** The `ScrapingMode` enum has been replaced with a strategy pattern. Use `WebScrapingStrategy` (default) or `LXMLWebScrapingStrategy`.

### 7\. Proxy Rotation

Added `ProxyRotationStrategy` abstract base class with `RoundRobinProxyStrategy` concrete implementation.

Other Changes and Improvements
------------------------------

*   **Added: `LLMContentFilter` for intelligent markdown generation.** This new filter uses an LLM to create more focused and relevant markdown output.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-1) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig, DefaultMarkdownGenerator [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-2) from crawl4ai.content_filter_strategy import LLMContentFilter [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-3) from crawl4ai import LLMConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-4) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-6) llm_config = LLMConfig(provider="gemini/gemini-1.5-pro", api_token="env:GEMINI_API_KEY") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-8) markdown_generator = DefaultMarkdownGenerator( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-9)     content_filter=LLMContentFilter(llm_config=llm_config, instruction="Extract key concepts and summaries") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-10) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-11) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-12) config = CrawlerRunConfig(markdown_generator=markdown_generator) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-13) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-14)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-15)         result = await crawler.arun("https://docs.crawl4ai.com", config=config) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-16)         print(result.markdown.fit_markdown) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-17) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-6-18) asyncio.run(main())`

*   **Added: URL redirection tracking.** The crawler now automatically follows HTTP redirects (301, 302, 307, 308) and records the final URL in the `redirected_url` field of the `CrawlResult` object. No code changes are required to enable this; it's automatic.
    
*   **Added: LLM-powered schema generation utility.** A new `generate_schema` method has been added to `JsonCssExtractionStrategy` and `JsonXPathExtractionStrategy`. This greatly simplifies creating extraction schemas.
    

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-1) from crawl4ai import JsonCssExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-2) from crawl4ai import LLMConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-4) llm_config = LLMConfig(provider="gemini/gemini-1.5-pro", api_token="env:GEMINI_API_KEY") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-6) schema = JsonCssExtractionStrategy.generate_schema( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-7)     html="<div class='product'><h2>Product Name</h2><span class='price'>$99</span></div>", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-8)     llm_config = llm_config, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-9)     query="Extract product name and price" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-10) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-7-11) print(schema)`

Expected Output (may vary slightly due to LLM)

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-8-1) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-8-2)   "name": "ProductExtractor", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-8-3)   "baseSelector": "div.product", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-8-4)   "fields": [ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-8-5)       {"name": "name", "selector": "h2", "type": "text"}, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-8-6)       {"name": "price", "selector": ".price", "type": "text"} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-8-7)     ] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-8-8)  }`

*   **Added: robots.txt compliance support.** The crawler can now respect `robots.txt` rules. Enable this by setting `check_robots_txt=True` in `CrawlerRunConfig`.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-9-1) config = CrawlerRunConfig(check_robots_txt=True)`

*   **Added: PDF processing capabilities.** Crawl4AI can now extract text, images, and metadata from PDF files (both local and remote). This uses a new `PDFCrawlerStrategy` and `PDFContentScrapingStrategy`.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-1) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-2) from crawl4ai.processors.pdf import PDFCrawlerStrategy, PDFContentScrapingStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-3) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-5) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-6)     async with AsyncWebCrawler(crawler_strategy=PDFCrawlerStrategy()) as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-7)         result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-8)             "https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.06825.pdf", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-9)             config=CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-10)                 scraping_strategy=PDFContentScrapingStrategy() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-11)             ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-12)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-13)         print(result.markdown)  # Access extracted text [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-14)         print(result.metadata)  # Access PDF metadata (title, author, etc.) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-15) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-10-16) asyncio.run(main())`

*   **Added: Support for frozenset serialization.** Improves configuration serialization, especially for sets of allowed/blocked domains. No code changes required.
    
*   **Added: New `LLMConfig` parameter.** This new parameter can be passed for extraction, filtering, and schema generation tasks. It simplifies passing provider strings, API tokens, and base URLs across all sections where LLM configuration is necessary. It also enables reuse and allows for quick experimentation between different LLM configurations.
    

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-1) from crawl4ai import LLMConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-2) from crawl4ai import LLMExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-3) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-5) # Example of using LLMConfig with LLMExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-6) llm_config = LLMConfig(provider="openai/gpt-4o", api_token="YOUR_API_KEY") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-7) strategy = LLMExtractionStrategy(llm_config=llm_config, schema=...) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-9) # Example usage within a crawler [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-10) async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-11)     result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-12)         url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-13)         config=CrawlerRunConfig(extraction_strategy=strategy) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/releases/0.5.0/#__codelineno-11-14)     )`

**Breaking Change:** Removed old parameters like `provider`, `api_token`, `base_url`, and `api_base` from `LLMExtractionStrategy` and `LLMContentFilter`. Users should migrate to using the `LLMConfig` object.

*   **Changed: Improved browser context management and added shared data support. (Breaking Change:** `BrowserContext` API updated). Browser contexts are now managed more efficiently, reducing resource usage. A new `shared_data` dictionary is available in the `BrowserContext` to allow passing data between different stages of the crawling process. **Breaking Change:** The `BrowserContext` API has changed, and the old `get_context` method is deprecated.
    
*   **Changed:** Renamed `final_url` to `redirected_url` in `CrawledURL`. This improves consistency and clarity. Update any code referencing the old field name.
    
*   **Changed:** Improved type hints and removed unused files. This is an internal improvement and should not require code changes.
    
*   **Changed:** Reorganized deep crawling functionality into dedicated module. (**Breaking Change:** Import paths for `DeepCrawlStrategy` and related classes have changed). This improves code organization. Update imports to use the new `crawl4ai.deep_crawling` module.
    
*   **Changed:** Improved HTML handling and cleanup codebase. (**Breaking Change:** Removed `ssl_certificate.json` file). This removes an unused file. If you were relying on this file for custom certificate validation, you'll need to implement an alternative approach.
    
*   **Changed:** Enhanced serialization and config handling. (**Breaking Change:** `FastFilterChain` has been replaced with `FilterChain`). This change simplifies config and improves the serialization.
    
*   **Added:** Modified the license to Apache 2.0 _with a required attribution clause_. See the `LICENSE` file for details. All users must now clearly attribute the Crawl4AI project when using, distributing, or creating derivative works.
    
*   **Fixed:** Prevent memory leaks by ensuring proper closure of Playwright pages. No code changes required.
    
*   **Fixed:** Make model fields optional with default values (**Breaking Change:** Code relying on all fields being present may need adjustment). Fields in data models (like `CrawledURL`) are now optional, with default values (usually `None`). Update code to handle potential `None` values.
    
*   **Fixed:** Adjust memory threshold and fix dispatcher initialization. This is an internal bug fix; no code changes are required.
    
*   **Fixed:** Ensure proper exit after running doctor command. No code changes are required.
    
*   **Fixed:** JsonCss selector and crawler improvements.
*   **Fixed:** Not working long page screenshot (#403)
*   **Documentation:** Updated documentation URLs to the new domain.
*   **Documentation:** Added SERP API project example.
*   **Documentation:** Added clarifying comments for CSS selector behavior.
*   **Documentation:** Add Code of Conduct for the project (#410)

Breaking Changes Summary
------------------------

*   **Dispatcher:** The `MemoryAdaptiveDispatcher` is now the default for `arun_many()`, changing concurrency behavior. The return type of `arun_many` depends on the `stream` parameter.
*   **Deep Crawling:** `max_depth` is now part of `CrawlerRunConfig` and controls crawl depth. Import paths for deep crawling strategies have changed.
*   **Browser Context:** The `BrowserContext` API has been updated.
*   **Models:** Many fields in data models are now optional, with default values.
*   **Scraping Mode:** `ScrapingMode` enum replaced by strategy pattern (`WebScrapingStrategy`, `LXMLWebScrapingStrategy`).
*   **Content Filter:** Removed `content_filter` parameter from `CrawlerRunConfig`. Use extraction strategies or markdown generators with filters instead.
*   **Removed:** Synchronous `WebCrawler`, CLI, and docs management functionality.
*   **Docker:** Significant changes to Docker deployment, including new requirements and configuration.
*   **File Removed**: Removed ssl\_certificate.json file which might affect existing certificate validations
*   **Renamed**: final\_url to redirected\_url for consistency
*   **Config**: FastFilterChain has been replaced with FilterChain
*   **Deep-Crawl**: DeepCrawlStrategy.arun now returns Union\[CrawlResultT, List\[CrawlResultT\], AsyncGenerator\[CrawlResultT, None\]\]
*   **Proxy**: Removed synchronous WebCrawler support and related rate limiting configurations

Migration Guide
---------------

1.  **Update Imports:** Adjust imports for `DeepCrawlStrategy`, `BreadthFirstSearchStrategy`, and related classes due to the new `deep_crawling` module structure.
2.  **`CrawlerRunConfig`:** Move `max_depth` to `CrawlerRunConfig`. If using `content_filter`, migrate to an extraction strategy or a markdown generator with a filter.
3.  **`arun_many()`:** Adapt code to the new `MemoryAdaptiveDispatcher` behavior and the return type.
4.  **`BrowserContext`:** Update code using the `BrowserContext` API.
5.  **Models:** Handle potential `None` values for optional fields in data models.
6.  **Scraping:** Replace `ScrapingMode` enum with `WebScrapingStrategy` or `LXMLWebScrapingStrategy`.
7.  **Docker:** Review the updated Docker documentation and adjust your deployment accordingly.
8.  **CLI:** Migrate to the new `crwl` command and update any scripts using the old CLI.
9.  **Proxy:**: Removed synchronous WebCrawler support and related rate limiting configurations.
10.  **Config:**: Replace FastFilterChain to FilterChain

# Installation - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Installation & Setup (2023 Edition)
===================================

1\. Basic Installation
----------------------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-0-1) pip install crawl4ai`

This installs the **core** Crawl4AI library along with essential dependencies. **No** advanced features (like transformers or PyTorch) are included yet.

2\. Initial Setup & Diagnostics
-------------------------------

### 2.1 Run the Setup Command

After installing, call:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-1-1) crawl4ai-setup`

**What does it do?** - Installs or updates required Playwright browsers (Chromium, Firefox, etc.) - Performs OS-level checks (e.g., missing libs on Linux) - Confirms your environment is ready to crawl

### 2.2 Diagnostics

Optionally, you can run **diagnostics** to confirm everything is functioning:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-2-1) crawl4ai-doctor`

This command attempts to: - Check Python version compatibility - Verify Playwright installation - Inspect environment variables or library conflicts

If any issues arise, follow its suggestions (e.g., installing additional system packages) and re-run `crawl4ai-setup`.

* * *

3\. Verifying Installation: A Simple Crawl (Skip this step if you already run `crawl4ai-doctor`)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Below is a minimal Python script demonstrating a **basic** crawl. It uses our new **`BrowserConfig`** and **`CrawlerRunConfig`** for clarity, though no custom settings are passed in this example:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-2) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, BrowserConfig, CrawlerRunConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-4) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-5)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-6)         result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-7)             url="https://www.example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-8)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-9)         print(result.markdown[:300])  # Show the first 300 characters of extracted text [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-11) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-3-12)     asyncio.run(main())`

**Expected** outcome: - A headless browser session loads `example.com` - Crawl4AI returns ~300 characters of markdown.  
If errors occur, rerun `crawl4ai-doctor` or manually ensure Playwright is installed correctly.

* * *

4\. Advanced Installation (Optional)
------------------------------------

**Warning**: Only install these **if you truly need them**. They bring in larger dependencies, including big models, which can increase disk usage and memory load significantly.

### 4.1 Torch, Transformers, or All

*   **Text Clustering (Torch)**  
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-4-1) pip install crawl4ai[torch] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-4-2) crawl4ai-setup`
    
    Installs PyTorch-based features (e.g., cosine similarity or advanced semantic chunking).
    
*   **Transformers**  
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-5-1) pip install crawl4ai[transformer] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-5-2) crawl4ai-setup`
    
    Adds Hugging Face-based summarization or generation strategies.
    
*   **All Features**  
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-6-1) pip install crawl4ai[all] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-6-2) crawl4ai-setup`
    

#### (Optional) Pre-Fetching Models

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-7-1) crawl4ai-download-models`

This step caches large models locally (if needed). **Only do this** if your workflow requires them.

* * *

5\. Docker (Experimental)
-------------------------

We provide a **temporary** Docker approach for testing. **It’s not stable and may break** with future releases. We plan a major Docker revamp in a future stable version, 2025 Q1. If you still want to try:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-8-1) docker pull unclecode/crawl4ai:basic [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/installation/#__codelineno-8-2) docker run -p 11235:11235 unclecode/crawl4ai:basic`

You can then make POST requests to `http://localhost:11235/crawl` to perform crawls. **Production usage** is discouraged until our new Docker approach is ready (planned in Jan or Feb 2025).

* * *

6\. Local Server Mode (Legacy)
------------------------------

Some older docs mention running Crawl4AI as a local server. This approach has been **partially replaced** by the new Docker-based prototype and upcoming stable server release. You can experiment, but expect major changes. Official local server instructions will arrive once the new Docker architecture is finalized.

* * *

Summary
-------

1. **Install** with `pip install crawl4ai` and run `crawl4ai-setup`. 2. **Diagnose** with `crawl4ai-doctor` if you see errors. 3. **Verify** by crawling `example.com` with minimal `BrowserConfig` + `CrawlerRunConfig`. 4. **Advanced** features (Torch, Transformers) are **optional**—avoid them if you don’t need them (they significantly increase resource usage). 5. **Docker** is **experimental**—use at your own risk until the stable version is released. 6. **Local server** references in older docs are largely deprecated; a new solution is in progress.

**Got questions?** Check [GitHub issues](https://github.com/unclecode/crawl4ai/issues)
 for updates or ask the community!

* * *
