* * *

6\. Scraping Modes
------------------

Crawl4AI provides two different scraping strategies for HTML content processing: `WebScrapingStrategy` (BeautifulSoup-based, default) and `LXMLWebScrapingStrategy` (LXML-based). The LXML strategy offers significantly better performance, especially for large HTML documents.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-1) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig, LXMLWebScrapingStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-3) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-4)     config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-5)         scraping_strategy=LXMLWebScrapingStrategy()  # Faster alternative to default BeautifulSoup [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-6)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-7)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-8)         result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-9)             url="https://example.com",  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-10)             config=config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-10-11)         )`

You can also create your own custom scraping strategy by inheriting from `ContentScrapingStrategy`. The strategy must return a `ScrapingResult` object with the following structure:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-1) from crawl4ai import ContentScrapingStrategy, ScrapingResult, MediaItem, Media, Link, Links [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-3) class CustomScrapingStrategy(ContentScrapingStrategy): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-4)     def scrap(self, url: str, html: str, **kwargs) -> ScrapingResult: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-5)         # Implement your custom scraping logic here [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-6)         return ScrapingResult( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-7)             cleaned_html="<html>...</html>",  # Cleaned HTML content [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-8)             success=True,                     # Whether scraping was successful [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-9)             media=Media( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-10)                 images=[                      # List of images found [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-11)                     MediaItem( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-12)                         src="https://example.com/image.jpg", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-13)                         alt="Image description", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-14)                         desc="Surrounding text", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-15)                         score=1, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-16)                         type="image", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-17)                         group_id=1, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-18)                         format="jpg", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-19)                         width=800 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-20)                     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-21)                 ], [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-22)                 videos=[],                    # List of videos (same structure as images) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-23)                 audios=[]                     # List of audio files (same structure as images) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-24)             ), [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-25)             links=Links( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-26)                 internal=[                    # List of internal links [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-27)                     Link( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-28)                         href="https://example.com/page", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-29)                         text="Link text", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-30)                         title="Link title", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-31)                         base_domain="example.com" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-32)                     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-33)                 ], [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-34)                 external=[]                   # List of external links (same structure) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-35)             ), [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-36)             metadata={                        # Additional metadata [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-37)                 "title": "Page Title", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-38)                 "description": "Page description" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-39)             } [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-40)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-41) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-42)     async def ascrap(self, url: str, html: str, **kwargs) -> ScrapingResult: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-43)         # For simple cases, you can use the sync version [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-11-44)         return await asyncio.to_thread(self.scrap, url, html, **kwargs)`

### Performance Considerations

The LXML strategy can be up to 10-20x faster than BeautifulSoup strategy, particularly when processing large HTML documents. However, please note:

1.  LXML strategy is currently experimental
2.  In some edge cases, the parsing results might differ slightly from BeautifulSoup
3.  If you encounter any inconsistencies between LXML and BeautifulSoup results, please [raise an issue](https://github.com/codeium/crawl4ai/issues)
     with a reproducible example

Choose LXML strategy when: - Processing large HTML documents (recommended for >100KB) - Performance is critical - Working with well-formed HTML

Stick to BeautifulSoup strategy (default) when: - Maximum compatibility is needed - Working with malformed HTML - Exact parsing behavior is critical

* * *

7\. Combining CSS Selection Methods
-----------------------------------

You can combine `css_selector` and `target_elements` in powerful ways to achieve fine-grained control over your output:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-2) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig, CacheMode [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-4) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-5)     # Target specific content but preserve page context [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-6)     config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-7)         # Focus markdown on main content and sidebar [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-8)         target_elements=["#main-content", ".sidebar"], [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-9) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-10)         # Global filters applied to entire page [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-11)         excluded_tags=["nav", "footer", "header"], [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-12)         exclude_external_links=True, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-14)         # Use basic content thresholds [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-15)         word_count_threshold=15, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-16) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-17)         cache_mode=CacheMode.BYPASS [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-18)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-19) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-20)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-21)         result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-22)             url="https://example.com/article", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-23)             config=config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-24)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-25) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-26)         print(f"Content focuses on specific elements, but all links still analyzed") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-27)         print(f"Internal links: {len(result.links.get('internal', []))}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-28)         print(f"External links: {len(result.links.get('external', []))}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-29) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-30) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/content-selection/#__codelineno-12-31)     asyncio.run(main())`

This approach gives you the best of both worlds: - Markdown generation and content extraction focus on the elements you care about - Links, images and other page data still give you the full context of the page - Content filtering still applies globally

8\. Conclusion
--------------

By mixing **target\_elements** or **css\_selector** scoping, **content filtering** parameters, and advanced **extraction strategies**, you can precisely **choose** which data to keep. Key parameters in **`CrawlerRunConfig`** for content selection include:

1.  **`target_elements`** – Array of CSS selectors to focus markdown generation and data extraction, while preserving full page context for links and media.
2.  **`css_selector`** – Basic scoping to an element or region for all extraction processes.
3.  **`word_count_threshold`** – Skip short blocks.
4.  **`excluded_tags`** – Remove entire HTML tags.
5.  **`exclude_external_links`**, **`exclude_social_media_links`**, **`exclude_domains`** – Filter out unwanted links or domains.
6.  **`exclude_external_images`** – Remove images from external sources.
7.  **`process_iframes`** – Merge iframe content if needed.

Combine these with structured extraction (CSS, LLM-based, or others) to build powerful crawls that yield exactly the content you want, from raw or cleaned HTML up to sophisticated JSON structures. For more detail, see [Configuration Reference](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/api/parameters/)
. Enjoy curating your data to the max!

* * *

# Chunking - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Chunking Strategies
===================

Chunking strategies are critical for dividing large texts into manageable parts, enabling effective content processing and extraction. These strategies are foundational in cosine similarity-based extraction techniques, which allow users to retrieve only the most relevant chunks of content for a given query. Additionally, they facilitate direct integration into RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) systems for structured and scalable workflows.

### Why Use Chunking?

1. **Cosine Similarity and Query Relevance**: Prepares chunks for semantic similarity analysis. 2. **RAG System Integration**: Seamlessly processes and stores chunks for retrieval. 3. **Structured Processing**: Allows for diverse segmentation methods, such as sentence-based, topic-based, or windowed approaches.

### Methods of Chunking

#### 1\. Regex-Based Chunking

Splits text based on regular expression patterns, useful for coarse segmentation.

**Code Example**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-1) class RegexChunking: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-2)     def __init__(self, patterns=None): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-3)         self.patterns = patterns or [r'\n\n']  # Default pattern for paragraphs [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-5)     def chunk(self, text): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-6)         paragraphs = [text] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-7)         for pattern in self.patterns: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-8)             paragraphs = [seg for p in paragraphs for seg in re.split(pattern, p)] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-9)         return paragraphs [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-11) # Example Usage [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-12) text = """This is the first paragraph. [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-14) This is the second paragraph.""" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-15) chunker = RegexChunking() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-0-16) print(chunker.chunk(text))`

#### 2\. Sentence-Based Chunking

Divides text into sentences using NLP tools, ideal for extracting meaningful statements.

**Code Example**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-1) from nltk.tokenize import sent_tokenize [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-3) class NlpSentenceChunking: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-4)     def chunk(self, text): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-5)         sentences = sent_tokenize(text) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-6)         return [sentence.strip() for sentence in sentences] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-8) # Example Usage [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-9) text = "This is sentence one. This is sentence two." [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-10) chunker = NlpSentenceChunking() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-1-11) print(chunker.chunk(text))`

#### 3\. Topic-Based Segmentation

Uses algorithms like TextTiling to create topic-coherent chunks.

**Code Example**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-1) from nltk.tokenize import TextTilingTokenizer [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-3) class TopicSegmentationChunking: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-4)     def __init__(self): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-5)         self.tokenizer = TextTilingTokenizer() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-7)     def chunk(self, text): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-8)         return self.tokenizer.tokenize(text) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-9) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-10) # Example Usage [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-11) text = """This is an introduction. [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-12) This is a detailed discussion on the topic.""" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-13) chunker = TopicSegmentationChunking() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-2-14) print(chunker.chunk(text))`

#### 4\. Fixed-Length Word Chunking

Segments text into chunks of a fixed word count.

**Code Example**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-1) class FixedLengthWordChunking: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-2)     def __init__(self, chunk_size=100): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-3)         self.chunk_size = chunk_size [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-5)     def chunk(self, text): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-6)         words = text.split() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-7)         return [' '.join(words[i:i + self.chunk_size]) for i in range(0, len(words), self.chunk_size)] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-9) # Example Usage [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-10) text = "This is a long text with many words to be chunked into fixed sizes." [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-11) chunker = FixedLengthWordChunking(chunk_size=5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-3-12) print(chunker.chunk(text))`

#### 5\. Sliding Window Chunking

Generates overlapping chunks for better contextual coherence.

**Code Example**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-1) class SlidingWindowChunking: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-2)     def __init__(self, window_size=100, step=50): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-3)         self.window_size = window_size [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-4)         self.step = step [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-6)     def chunk(self, text): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-7)         words = text.split() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-8)         chunks = [] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-9)         for i in range(0, len(words) - self.window_size + 1, self.step): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-10)             chunks.append(' '.join(words[i:i + self.window_size])) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-11)         return chunks [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-12) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-13) # Example Usage [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-14) text = "This is a long text to demonstrate sliding window chunking." [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-15) chunker = SlidingWindowChunking(window_size=5, step=2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-4-16) print(chunker.chunk(text))`

### Combining Chunking with Cosine Similarity

To enhance the relevance of extracted content, chunking strategies can be paired with cosine similarity techniques. Here’s an example workflow:

**Code Example**:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-1) from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import TfidfVectorizer [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-2) from sklearn.metrics.pairwise import cosine_similarity [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-4) class CosineSimilarityExtractor: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-5)     def __init__(self, query): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-6)         self.query = query [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-7)         self.vectorizer = TfidfVectorizer() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-9)     def find_relevant_chunks(self, chunks): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-10)         vectors = self.vectorizer.fit_transform([self.query] + chunks) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-11)         similarities = cosine_similarity(vectors[0:1], vectors[1:]).flatten() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-12)         return [(chunks[i], similarities[i]) for i in range(len(chunks))] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-14) # Example Workflow [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-15) text = """This is a sample document. It has multiple sentences.  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-16) We are testing chunking and similarity.""" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-17) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-18) chunker = SlidingWindowChunking(window_size=5, step=3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-19) chunks = chunker.chunk(text) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-20) query = "testing chunking" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-21) extractor = CosineSimilarityExtractor(query) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-22) relevant_chunks = extractor.find_relevant_chunks(chunks) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-23) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/chunking/#__codelineno-5-24) print(relevant_chunks)`

# Clustering Strategies - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Cosine Strategy
===============

The Cosine Strategy in Crawl4AI uses similarity-based clustering to identify and extract relevant content sections from web pages. This strategy is particularly useful when you need to find and extract content based on semantic similarity rather than structural patterns.

How It Works
------------

The Cosine Strategy: 1. Breaks down page content into meaningful chunks 2. Converts text into vector representations 3. Calculates similarity between chunks 4. Clusters similar content together 5. Ranks and filters content based on relevance

Basic Usage
-----------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-1) from crawl4ai import CosineStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-3) strategy = CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-4)     semantic_filter="product reviews",    # Target content type [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-5)     word_count_threshold=10,             # Minimum words per cluster [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-6)     sim_threshold=0.3                    # Similarity threshold [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-7) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-9) async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-10)     result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-11)         url="https://example.com/reviews", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-12)         extraction_strategy=strategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-13)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-14) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-0-15)     content = result.extracted_content`

Configuration Options
---------------------

### Core Parameters

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-1) CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-2)     # Content Filtering [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-3)     semantic_filter: str = None,       # Keywords/topic for content filtering [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-4)     word_count_threshold: int = 10,    # Minimum words per cluster [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-5)     sim_threshold: float = 0.3,        # Similarity threshold (0.0 to 1.0) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-7)     # Clustering Parameters [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-8)     max_dist: float = 0.2,            # Maximum distance for clustering [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-9)     linkage_method: str = 'ward',      # Clustering linkage method [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-10)     top_k: int = 3,                   # Number of top categories to extract [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-11) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-12)     # Model Configuration [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-13)     model_name: str = 'sentence-transformers/all-MiniLM-L6-v2',  # Embedding model [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-14) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-15)     verbose: bool = False             # Enable logging [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-1-16) )`

### Parameter Details

1. **semantic\_filter** - Sets the target topic or content type - Use keywords relevant to your desired content - Example: "technical specifications", "user reviews", "pricing information"

2. **sim\_threshold** - Controls how similar content must be to be grouped together - Higher values (e.g., 0.8) mean stricter matching - Lower values (e.g., 0.3) allow more variation

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-2-1) # Strict matching [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-2-2) strategy = CosineStrategy(sim_threshold=0.8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-2-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-2-4) # Loose matching [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-2-5) strategy = CosineStrategy(sim_threshold=0.3)`

3. **word\_count\_threshold** - Filters out short content blocks - Helps eliminate noise and irrelevant content

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-3-1) # Only consider substantial paragraphs [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-3-2) strategy = CosineStrategy(word_count_threshold=50)`

4. **top\_k** - Number of top content clusters to return - Higher values return more diverse content

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-4-1) # Get top 5 most relevant content clusters [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-4-2) strategy = CosineStrategy(top_k=5)`

Use Cases
---------

### 1\. Article Content Extraction

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-5-1) strategy = CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-5-2)     semantic_filter="main article content", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-5-3)     word_count_threshold=100,  # Longer blocks for articles [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-5-4)     top_k=1                   # Usually want single main content [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-5-5) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-5-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-5-7) result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-5-8)     url="https://example.com/blog/post", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-5-9)     extraction_strategy=strategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-5-10) )`

### 2\. Product Review Analysis

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-6-1) strategy = CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-6-2)     semantic_filter="customer reviews and ratings", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-6-3)     word_count_threshold=20,   # Reviews can be shorter [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-6-4)     top_k=10,                 # Get multiple reviews [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-6-5)     sim_threshold=0.4         # Allow variety in review content [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-6-6) )`

### 3\. Technical Documentation

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-7-1) strategy = CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-7-2)     semantic_filter="technical specifications documentation", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-7-3)     word_count_threshold=30, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-7-4)     sim_threshold=0.6,        # Stricter matching for technical content [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-7-5)     max_dist=0.3             # Allow related technical sections [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-7-6) )`

Advanced Features
-----------------

### Custom Clustering

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-8-1) strategy = CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-8-2)     linkage_method='complete',  # Alternative clustering method [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-8-3)     max_dist=0.4,              # Larger clusters [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-8-4)     model_name='sentence-transformers/paraphrase-multilingual-MiniLM-L12-v2'  # Multilingual support [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-8-5) )`

### Content Filtering Pipeline

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-1) strategy = CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-2)     semantic_filter="pricing plans features", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-3)     word_count_threshold=15, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-4)     sim_threshold=0.5, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-5)     top_k=3 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-6) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-8) async def extract_pricing_features(url: str): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-9)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-10)         result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-11)             url=url, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-12)             extraction_strategy=strategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-13)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-14) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-15)         if result.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-16) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-18)                 'pricing_features': content, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-19)                 'clusters': len(content), [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-20)                 'similarity_scores': [item['score'] for item in content] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-9-21)             }`

Best Practices
--------------

1. **Adjust Thresholds Iteratively** - Start with default values - Adjust based on results - Monitor clustering quality

2. **Choose Appropriate Word Count Thresholds** - Higher for articles (100+) - Lower for reviews/comments (20+) - Medium for product descriptions (50+)

3. **Optimize Performance**

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-10-1) strategy = CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-10-2)     word_count_threshold=10,  # Filter early [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-10-3)     top_k=5,                 # Limit results [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-10-4)     verbose=True             # Monitor performance [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-10-5) )`

4. **Handle Different Content Types**

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-11-1) # For mixed content pages [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-11-2) strategy = CosineStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-11-3)     semantic_filter="product features", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-11-4)     sim_threshold=0.4,      # More flexible matching [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-11-5)     max_dist=0.3,          # Larger clusters [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-11-6)     top_k=3                # Multiple relevant sections [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-11-7) )`

Error Handling
--------------

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-1) try: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-2)     result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-3)         url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-4)         extraction_strategy=strategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-5)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-7)     if result.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-8)         content = json.loads(result.extracted_content) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-9)         if not content: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-10)             print("No relevant content found") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-11)     else: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-12)         print(f"Extraction failed: {result.error_message}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-14) except Exception as e: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/clustring-strategies/#__codelineno-12-15)     print(f"Error during extraction: {str(e)}")`

The Cosine Strategy is particularly effective when: - Content structure is inconsistent - You need semantic understanding - You want to find similar content blocks - Structure-based extraction (CSS/XPath) isn't reliable

It works well with other strategies and can be used as a pre-processing step for LLM-based extraction.

Prerequisites
-------------

Before we dive in, make sure you have: - Docker installed and running (version 20.10.0 or higher), including `docker compose` (usually bundled with Docker Desktop). - `git` for cloning the repository. - At least 4GB of RAM available for the container (more recommended for heavy use). - Python 3.10+ (if using the Python SDK). - Node.js 16+ (if using the Node.js examples).

> 💡 **Pro tip**: Run `docker info` to check your Docker installation and available resources.

Installation
------------

We offer several ways to get the Crawl4AI server running. The quickest way is to use our pre-built Docker Hub images.

### Option 1: Using Pre-built Docker Hub Images (Recommended)

Pull and run images directly from Docker Hub without building locally.

#### 1\. Pull the Image

Our latest release candidate is `0.7.0-r1`. Images are built with multi-arch manifests, so Docker automatically pulls the correct version for your system.

> ⚠️ **Important Note**: The `latest` tag currently points to the stable `0.6.0` version. After testing and validation, `0.7.0` (without -r1) will be released and `latest` will be updated. For now, please use `0.7.0-r1` to test the new features.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-0-1) # Pull the release candidate (for testing new features) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-0-2) docker pull unclecode/crawl4ai:0.7.0-r1 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-0-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-0-4) # Or pull the current stable version (0.6.0) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-0-5) docker pull unclecode/crawl4ai:latest`

#### 2\. Setup Environment (API Keys)

If you plan to use LLMs, create a `.llm.env` file in your working directory:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-1) # Create a .llm.env file with your API keys [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-2) cat > .llm.env << EOL [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-3) # OpenAI [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-4) OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-your-key [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-6) # Anthropic [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-7) ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your-anthropic-key [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-9) # Other providers as needed [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-10) # DEEPSEEK_API_KEY=your-deepseek-key [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-11) # GROQ_API_KEY=your-groq-key [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-12) # TOGETHER_API_KEY=your-together-key [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-13) # MISTRAL_API_KEY=your-mistral-key [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-14) # GEMINI_API_TOKEN=your-gemini-token [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-1-15) EOL`

> 🔑 **Note**: Keep your API keys secure! Never commit `.llm.env` to version control.

#### 3\. Run the Container

*   **Basic run:**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-2-1) docker run -d \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-2-2)   -p 11235:11235 \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-2-3)   --name crawl4ai \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-2-4)   --shm-size=1g \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-2-5)   unclecode/crawl4ai:latest`
    
*   **With LLM support:**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-3-1) # Make sure .llm.env is in the current directory [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-3-2) docker run -d \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-3-3)   -p 11235:11235 \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-3-4)   --name crawl4ai \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-3-5)   --env-file .llm.env \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-3-6)   --shm-size=1g \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-3-7)   unclecode/crawl4ai:latest`
    

> The server will be available at `http://localhost:11235`. Visit `/playground` to access the interactive testing interface.

#### 4\. Stopping the Container

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-4-1) docker stop crawl4ai && docker rm crawl4ai`

#### Docker Hub Versioning Explained

*   **Image Name:** `unclecode/crawl4ai`
*   **Tag Format:** `LIBRARY_VERSION[-SUFFIX]` (e.g., `0.7.0-r1`)
    *   `LIBRARY_VERSION`: The semantic version of the core `crawl4ai` Python library
    *   `SUFFIX`: Optional tag for release candidates (`` `) and revisions ( ``r1\`)
*   **`latest` Tag:** Points to the most recent stable version
*   **Multi-Architecture Support:** All images support both `linux/amd64` and `linux/arm64` architectures through a single tag

### Option 2: Using Docker Compose

Docker Compose simplifies building and running the service, especially for local development and testing.

#### 1\. Clone Repository

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-5-1) git clone https://github.com/unclecode/crawl4ai.git [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-5-2) cd crawl4ai`

#### 2\. Environment Setup (API Keys)

If you plan to use LLMs, copy the example environment file and add your API keys. This file should be in the **project root directory**.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-6-1) # Make sure you are in the 'crawl4ai' root directory [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-6-2) cp deploy/docker/.llm.env.example .llm.env [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-6-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-6-4) # Now edit .llm.env and add your API keys`

#### 3\. Build and Run with Compose

The `docker-compose.yml` file in the project root provides a simplified approach that automatically handles architecture detection using buildx.

*   **Run Pre-built Image from Docker Hub:**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-7-1) # Pulls and runs the release candidate from Docker Hub [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-7-2) # Automatically selects the correct architecture [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-7-3) IMAGE=unclecode/crawl4ai:latest docker compose up -d`
    
*   **Build and Run Locally:**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-8-1) # Builds the image locally using Dockerfile and runs it [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-8-2) # Automatically uses the correct architecture for your machine [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-8-3) docker compose up --build -d`
    
*   **Customize the Build:**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-9-1) # Build with all features (includes torch and transformers) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-9-2) INSTALL_TYPE=all docker compose up --build -d [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-9-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-9-4) # Build with GPU support (for AMD64 platforms) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-9-5) ENABLE_GPU=true docker compose up --build -d`
    

> The server will be available at `http://localhost:11235`.

#### 4\. Stopping the Service

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-10-1) # Stop the service [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-10-2) docker compose down`

### Option 3: Manual Local Build & Run

If you prefer not to use Docker Compose for direct control over the build and run process.

#### 1\. Clone Repository & Setup Environment

Follow steps 1 and 2 from the Docker Compose section above (clone repo, `cd crawl4ai`, create `.llm.env` in the root).

#### 2\. Build the Image (Multi-Arch)

Use `docker buildx` to build the image. Crawl4AI now uses buildx to handle multi-architecture builds automatically.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-1) # Make sure you are in the 'crawl4ai' root directory [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-2) # Build for the current architecture and load it into Docker [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-3) docker buildx build -t crawl4ai-local:latest --load . [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-5) # Or build for multiple architectures (useful for publishing) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-6) docker buildx build --platform linux/amd64,linux/arm64 -t crawl4ai-local:latest --load . [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-8) # Build with additional options [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-9) docker buildx build \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-10)   --build-arg INSTALL_TYPE=all \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-11)   --build-arg ENABLE_GPU=false \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-11-12)   -t crawl4ai-local:latest --load .`

#### 3\. Run the Container

*   **Basic run (no LLM support):**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-12-1) docker run -d \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-12-2)   -p 11235:11235 \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-12-3)   --name crawl4ai-standalone \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-12-4)   --shm-size=1g \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-12-5)   crawl4ai-local:latest`
    
*   **With LLM support:**
    
    `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-13-1) # Make sure .llm.env is in the current directory (project root) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-13-2) docker run -d \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-13-3)   -p 11235:11235 \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-13-4)   --name crawl4ai-standalone \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-13-5)   --env-file .llm.env \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-13-6)   --shm-size=1g \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-13-7)   crawl4ai-local:latest`

MCP (Model Context Protocol) Support
------------------------------------

Crawl4AI server includes support for the Model Context Protocol (MCP), allowing you to connect the server's capabilities directly to MCP-compatible clients like Claude Code.

### What is MCP?

MCP is an open protocol that standardizes how applications provide context to LLMs. It allows AI models to access external tools, data sources, and services through a standardized interface.

### Connecting via MCP

The Crawl4AI server exposes two MCP endpoints:

*   **Server-Sent Events (SSE)**: `http://localhost:11235/mcp/sse`
*   **WebSocket**: `ws://localhost:11235/mcp/ws`

### Using with Claude Code

You can add Crawl4AI as an MCP tool provider in Claude Code with a simple command:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-15-1) # Add the Crawl4AI server as an MCP provider [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-15-2) claude mcp add --transport sse c4ai-sse http://localhost:11235/mcp/sse [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-15-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-15-4) # List all MCP providers to verify it was added [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-15-5) claude mcp list`

Once connected, Claude Code can directly use Crawl4AI's capabilities like screenshot capture, PDF generation, and HTML processing without having to make separate API calls.

### Available MCP Tools

When connected via MCP, the following tools are available:

*   `md` - Generate markdown from web content
*   `html` - Extract preprocessed HTML
*   `screenshot` - Capture webpage screenshots
*   `pdf` - Generate PDF documents
*   `execute_js` - Run JavaScript on web pages
*   `crawl` - Perform multi-URL crawling
*   `ask` - Query the Crawl4AI library context

### Testing MCP Connections

You can test the MCP WebSocket connection using the test file included in the repository:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-16-1) # From the repository root [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-16-2) python tests/mcp/test_mcp_socket.py`

### MCP Schemas

Access the MCP tool schemas at `http://localhost:11235/mcp/schema` for detailed information on each tool's parameters and capabilities.

Additional API Endpoints
------------------------

In addition to the core `/crawl` and `/crawl/stream` endpoints, the server provides several specialized endpoints:

### HTML Extraction Endpoint

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-17-1) POST /html`

Crawls the URL and returns preprocessed HTML optimized for schema extraction.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-18-1) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-18-2)   "url": "https://example.com" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-18-3) }`

### Screenshot Endpoint

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-19-1) POST /screenshot`

Captures a full-page PNG screenshot of the specified URL.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-20-1) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-20-2)   "url": "https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-20-3)   "screenshot_wait_for": 2, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-20-4)   "output_path": "/path/to/save/screenshot.png" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-20-5) }`

*   `screenshot_wait_for`: Optional delay in seconds before capture (default: 2)
*   `output_path`: Optional path to save the screenshot (recommended)

### PDF Export Endpoint

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-21-1) POST /pdf`

Generates a PDF document of the specified URL.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-22-1) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-22-2)   "url": "https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-22-3)   "output_path": "/path/to/save/document.pdf" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-22-4) }`

*   `output_path`: Optional path to save the PDF (recommended)

### JavaScript Execution Endpoint

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-23-1) POST /execute_js`

Executes JavaScript snippets on the specified URL and returns the full crawl result.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-24-1) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-24-2)   "url": "https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-24-3)   "scripts": [ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-24-4)     "return document.title", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-24-5)     "return Array.from(document.querySelectorAll('a')).map(a => a.href)" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-24-6)   ] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-24-7) }`

*   `scripts`: List of JavaScript snippets to execute sequentially

Dockerfile Parameters
---------------------

You can customize the image build process using build arguments (`--build-arg`). These are typically used via `docker buildx build` or within the `docker-compose.yml` file.

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-25-1) # Example: Build with 'all' features using buildx [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-25-2) docker buildx build \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-25-3)   --platform linux/amd64,linux/arm64 \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-25-4)   --build-arg INSTALL_TYPE=all \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-25-5)   -t yourname/crawl4ai-all:latest \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-25-6)   --load \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-25-7)   . # Build from root context`

### Build Arguments Explained

| Argument | Description | Default | Options |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| INSTALL\_TYPE | Feature set | `default` | `default`, `all`, `torch`, `transformer` |
| ENABLE\_GPU | GPU support (CUDA for AMD64) | `false` | `true`, `false` |
| APP\_HOME | Install path inside container (advanced) | `/app` | any valid path |
| USE\_LOCAL | Install library from local source | `true` | `true`, `false` |
| GITHUB\_REPO | Git repo to clone if USE\_LOCAL=false | _(see Dockerfile)_ | any git URL |
| GITHUB\_BRANCH | Git branch to clone if USE\_LOCAL=false | `main` | any branch name |

_(Note: PYTHON\_VERSION is fixed by the `FROM` instruction in the Dockerfile)_

### Build Best Practices

1.  **Choose the Right Install Type**
    *   `default`: Basic installation, smallest image size. Suitable for most standard web scraping and markdown generation.
    *   `all`: Full features including `torch` and `transformers` for advanced extraction strategies (e.g., CosineStrategy, certain LLM filters). Significantly larger image. Ensure you need these extras.
2.  **Platform Considerations**
    *   Use `buildx` for building multi-architecture images, especially for pushing to registries.
    *   Use `docker compose` profiles (`local-amd64`, `local-arm64`) for easy platform-specific local builds.
3.  **Performance Optimization**
    *   The image automatically includes platform-specific optimizations (OpenMP for AMD64, OpenBLAS for ARM64).

Using the API
-------------

Communicate with the running Docker server via its REST API (defaulting to `http://localhost:11235`). You can use the Python SDK or make direct HTTP requests.

### Playground Interface

A built-in web playground is available at `http://localhost:11235/playground` for testing and generating API requests. The playground allows you to:

1.  Configure `CrawlerRunConfig` and `BrowserConfig` using the main library's Python syntax
2.  Test crawling operations directly from the interface
3.  Generate corresponding JSON for REST API requests based on your configuration

This is the easiest way to translate Python configuration to JSON requests when building integrations.

### Python SDK

Install the SDK: `pip install crawl4ai`

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-26-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-26-2) from crawl4ai.docker_client import Crawl4aiDockerClient [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-26-3) from crawl4ai import BrowserConfig, CrawlerRunConfig, CacheMode # Server Configuration
--------------------

The server's behavior can be customized through the `config.yml` file.

### Understanding config.yml

The configuration file is loaded from `/app/config.yml` inside the container. By default, the file from `deploy/docker/config.yml` in the repository is copied there during the build.

Here's a detailed breakdown of the configuration options (using defaults from `deploy/docker/config.yml`):

### Customizing Your Configuration

You can override the default `config.yml`.

#### Method 1: Modify Before Build

1.  Edit the `deploy/docker/config.yml` file in your local repository clone.
2.  Build the image using `docker buildx` or `docker compose --profile local-... up --build`. The modified file will be copied into the image.

#### Method 2: Runtime Mount (Recommended for Custom Deploys)

1.  Create your custom configuration file, e.g., `my-custom-config.yml` locally. Ensure it contains all necessary sections.
2.  Mount it when running the container:
    
    *   **Using `docker run`:**
        
        `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-32-1) # Assumes my-custom-config.yml is in the current directory [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-32-2) docker run -d -p 11235:11235 \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-32-3)   --name crawl4ai-custom-config \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-32-4)   --env-file .llm.env \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-32-5)   --shm-size=1g \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-32-6)   -v $(pwd)/my-custom-config.yml:/app/config.yml \ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-32-7)   unclecode/crawl4ai:latest # Or your specific tag`
        
    *   **Using `docker-compose.yml`:** Add a `volumes` section to the service definition:
        
        `[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-33-1) services: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-33-2)   crawl4ai-hub-amd64: # Or your chosen service [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-33-3)     image: unclecode/crawl4ai:latest [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-33-4)     profiles: ["hub-amd64"] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-33-5)     <<: *base-config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-33-6)     volumes: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-33-7)       # Mount local custom config over the default one in the container [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-33-8)       - ./my-custom-config.yml:/app/config.yml [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-33-9)       # Keep the shared memory volume from base-config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/docker-deployment/#__codelineno-33-10)       - /dev/shm:/dev/shm`
        
        _(Note: Ensure `my-custom-config.yml` is in the same directory as `docker-compose.yml`)_
        

> 💡 When mounting, your custom file _completely replaces_ the default one. Ensure it's a valid and complete configuration.

### Configuration Recommendations

1.  **Security First** 🔒
2.  Always enable security in production
3.  Use specific trusted\_hosts instead of wildcards
4.  Set up proper rate limiting to protect your server
5.  Consider your environment before enabling HTTPS redirect
    
6.  **Resource Management** 💻
    
7.  Adjust memory\_threshold\_percent based on available RAM
8.  Set timeouts according to your content size and network conditions
9.  Use Redis for rate limiting in multi-container setups
    
10.  **Monitoring** 📊
    
11.  Enable Prometheus if you need metrics
12.  Set DEBUG logging in development, INFO in production
13.  Regular health check monitoring is crucial
    
14.  **Performance Tuning** ⚡
    
15.  Start with conservative rate limiter delays
16.  Increase batch\_process timeout for large content
17.  Adjust stream\_init timeout based on initial response times

Getting Help
------------

We're here to help you succeed with Crawl4AI! Here's how to get support:

*   📖 Check our [full documentation](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/)
    
*   🐛 Found a bug? [Open an issue](https://github.com/unclecode/crawl4ai/issues)
    
*   💬 Join our [Discord community](https://discord.gg/crawl4ai)
    
*   ⭐ Star us on GitHub to show support!

Summary
-------

In this guide, we've covered everything you need to get started with Crawl4AI's Docker deployment: - Building and running the Docker container - Configuring the environment  
\- Using the interactive playground for testing - Making API requests with proper typing - Using the Python SDK - Leveraging specialized endpoints for screenshots, PDFs, and JavaScript execution - Connecting via the Model Context Protocol (MCP) - Monitoring your deployment

The new playground interface at `http://localhost:11235/playground` makes it much easier to test configurations and generate the corresponding JSON for API requests.

For AI application developers, the MCP integration allows tools like Claude Code to directly access Crawl4AI's capabilities without complex API handling.

Remember, the examples in the `examples` folder are your friends - they show real-world usage patterns that you can adapt for your needs.

Keep exploring, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need help! We're building something amazing together. 🚀

Happy crawling! 🕷️
