4\. RegexExtractionStrategy - Fast Pattern-Based Extraction
-----------------------------------------------------------

Crawl4AI now offers a powerful new zero-LLM extraction strategy: `RegexExtractionStrategy`. This strategy provides lightning-fast extraction of common data types like emails, phone numbers, URLs, dates, and more using pre-compiled regular expressions.

### Key Features

*   **Zero LLM Dependency**: Extracts data without any AI model calls
*   **Blazing Fast**: Uses pre-compiled regex patterns for maximum performance
*   **Built-in Patterns**: Includes ready-to-use patterns for common data types
*   **Custom Patterns**: Add your own regex patterns for domain-specific extraction
*   **LLM-Assisted Pattern Generation**: Optionally use an LLM once to generate optimized patterns, then reuse them without further LLM calls

### Simple Example: Extracting Common Entities

The easiest way to start is by using the built-in pattern catalog:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-1) import json [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-2) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-3) from crawl4ai import ( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-4)     AsyncWebCrawler, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-5)     CrawlerRunConfig, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-6)     RegexExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-7) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-9) async def extract_with_regex(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-10)     # Create a strategy using built-in patterns for URLs and currencies [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-11)     strategy = RegexExtractionStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-12)         pattern = RegexExtractionStrategy.Url | RegexExtractionStrategy.Currency [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-13)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-14) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-15)     config = CrawlerRunConfig(extraction_strategy=strategy) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-16) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-17)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-18)         result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-19)             url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-20)             config=config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-21)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-22) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-23)         if result.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-24)             data = json.loads(result.extracted_content) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-25)             for item in data[:5]:  # Show first 5 matches [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-26)                 print(f"{item['label']}: {item['value']}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-27)             print(f"Total matches: {len(data)}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-28) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-5-29) asyncio.run(extract_with_regex())`

### Available Built-in Patterns

`RegexExtractionStrategy` provides these common patterns as IntFlag attributes for easy combining:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-1) # Use individual patterns [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-2) strategy = RegexExtractionStrategy(pattern=RegexExtractionStrategy.Email) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-4) # Combine multiple patterns [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-5) strategy = RegexExtractionStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-6)     pattern = ( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-7)         RegexExtractionStrategy.Email |  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-8)         RegexExtractionStrategy.PhoneUS |  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-9)         RegexExtractionStrategy.Url [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-10)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-11) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-12) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-13) # Use all available patterns [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-6-14) strategy = RegexExtractionStrategy(pattern=RegexExtractionStrategy.All)`

Available patterns include: - `Email` - Email addresses - `PhoneIntl` - International phone numbers - `PhoneUS` - US-format phone numbers - `Url` - HTTP/HTTPS URLs - `IPv4` - IPv4 addresses - `IPv6` - IPv6 addresses - `Uuid` - UUIDs - `Currency` - Currency values (USD, EUR, etc.) - `Percentage` - Percentage values - `Number` - Numeric values - `DateIso` - ISO format dates - `DateUS` - US format dates - `Time24h` - 24-hour format times - `PostalUS` - US postal codes - `PostalUK` - UK postal codes - `HexColor` - HTML hex color codes - `TwitterHandle` - Twitter handles - `Hashtag` - Hashtags - `MacAddr` - MAC addresses - `Iban` - International bank account numbers - `CreditCard` - Credit card numbers

### Custom Pattern Example

For more targeted extraction, you can provide custom patterns:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-1) import json [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-2) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-3) from crawl4ai import ( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-4)     AsyncWebCrawler, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-5)     CrawlerRunConfig, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-6)     RegexExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-7) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-9) async def extract_prices(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-10)     # Define a custom pattern for US Dollar prices [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-11)     price_pattern = {"usd_price": r"\$\s?\d{1,3}(?:,\d{3})*(?:\.\d{2})?"} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-12) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-7-13)     # ### LLM-Assisted Pattern Generation

For complex or site-specific patterns, you can use an LLM once to generate an optimized pattern, then save and reuse it without further LLM calls:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-1) import json [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-2) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-3) from pathlib import Path [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-4) from crawl4ai import ( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-5)     AsyncWebCrawler, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-6)     CrawlerRunConfig, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-7)     RegexExtractionStrategy, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-8)     LLMConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-9) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-11) async def extract_with_generated_pattern(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-12)     cache_dir = Path("./pattern_cache") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-13)     cache_dir.mkdir(exist_ok=True) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-14)     pattern_file = cache_dir / "price_pattern.json" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-15) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-16)     # 1. Generate or load pattern [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-17)     if pattern_file.exists(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-18)         pattern = json.load(pattern_file.open()) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-19)         print(f"Using cached pattern: {pattern}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-20)     else: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-21)         print("Generating pattern via LLM...") Get sample HTML for context [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-30)         async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-31)             result = await crawler.arun("https://example.com/products") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-32)             html = result.fit_html [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-33) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-8-34)         # This pattern allows you to: 1. Use an LLM once to generate a highly optimized regex for your specific site 2. Save the pattern to disk for reuse 3. Extract data using only regex (no further LLM calls) in production

### Extraction Results Format

The `RegexExtractionStrategy` returns results in a consistent format:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-1) [ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-2)   { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-3)     "url": "https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-4)     "label": "email", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-5)     "value": "contact@example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-6)     "span": [145, 163] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-7)   }, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-8)   { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-9)     "url": "https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-10)     "label": "url", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-11)     "value": "https://support.example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-12)     "span": [210, 235] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-13)   } [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-9-14) ]`

Each match includes: - `url`: The source URL - `label`: The pattern name that matched (e.g., "email", "phone\_us") - `value`: The extracted text - `span`: The start and end positions in the source content

* * *

5\. Why "No LLM" Is Often Better
--------------------------------

1.  **Zero Hallucination**: Pattern-based extraction doesn't guess text. It either finds it or not.
2.  **Guaranteed Structure**: The same schema or regex yields consistent JSON across many pages, so your downstream pipeline can rely on stable keys.
3.  **Speed**: LLM-based extraction can be 10–1000x slower for large-scale crawling.
4.  **Scalable**: Adding or updating a field is a matter of adjusting the schema or regex, not re-tuning a model.

**When might you consider an LLM?** Possibly if the site is extremely unstructured or you want AI summarization. But always try a schema or regex approach first for repeated or consistent data patterns.

* * *

6\. Base Element Attributes & Additional Fields
-----------------------------------------------

It's easy to **extract attributes** (like `href`, `src`, or `data-xxx`) from your base or nested elements using:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-10-1) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-10-2)   "name": "href", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-10-3)   "type": "attribute", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-10-4)   "attribute": "href", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-10-5)   "default": null [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-10-6) }`

You can define them in **`baseFields`** (extracted from the main container element) or in each field's sub-lists. This is especially helpful if you need an item's link or ID stored in the parent `<div>`.

* * *

7\. Putting It All Together: Larger Example
-------------------------------------------

Consider a blog site. We have a schema that extracts the **URL** from each post card (via `baseFields` with an `"attribute": "href"`), plus the title, date, summary, and author:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-1) schema = { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-2)   "name": "Blog Posts", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-3)   "baseSelector": "a.blog-post-card", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-4)   "baseFields": [ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-5)     {"name": "post_url", "type": "attribute", "attribute": "href"} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-6)   ], [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-7)   "fields": [ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-8)     {"name": "title", "selector": "h2.post-title", "type": "text", "default": "No Title"}, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-9)     {"name": "date", "selector": "time.post-date", "type": "text", "default": ""}, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-10)     {"name": "summary", "selector": "p.post-summary", "type": "text", "default": ""}, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-11)     {"name": "author", "selector": "span.post-author", "type": "text", "default": ""} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-12)   ] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-11-13) }`

Then run with `JsonCssExtractionStrategy(schema)` to get an array of blog post objects, each with `"post_url"`, `"title"`, `"date"`, `"summary"`, `"author"`.

* * *

8\. Tips & Best Practices
-------------------------

1.  **Inspect the DOM** in Chrome DevTools or Firefox's Inspector to find stable selectors.
2.  **Start Simple**: Verify you can extract a single field. Then add complexity like nested objects or lists.
3.  **Test** your schema on partial HTML or a test page before a big crawl.
4.  **Combine with JS Execution** if the site loads content dynamically. You can pass `js_code` or `wait_for` in `CrawlerRunConfig`.
5.  **Look at Logs** when `verbose=True`: if your selectors are off or your schema is malformed, it'll often show warnings.
6.  **Use baseFields** if you need attributes from the container element (e.g., `href`, `data-id`), especially for the "parent" item.
7.  **Performance**: For large pages, make sure your selectors are as narrow as possible.
8.  **Consider Using Regex First**: For simple data types like emails, URLs, and dates, `RegexExtractionStrategy` is often the fastest approach.

* * *

9\. Schema Generation Utility
-----------------------------

While manually crafting schemas is powerful and precise, Crawl4AI now offers a convenient utility to **automatically generate** extraction schemas using LLM. This is particularly useful when:

1.  You're dealing with a new website structure and want a quick starting point
2.  You need to extract complex nested data structures
3.  You want to avoid the learning curve of CSS/XPath selector syntax

### Using the Schema Generator

The schema generator is available as a static method on both `JsonCssExtractionStrategy` and `JsonXPathExtractionStrategy`. You can choose between OpenAI's GPT-4 or the open-source Ollama for schema generation:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-1) from crawl4ai import JsonCssExtractionStrategy, JsonXPathExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-2) from crawl4ai import LLMConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-4) # Sample HTML with product information [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-5) html = """ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-6) <div class="product-card"> [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-7)     <h2 class="title">Gaming Laptop</h2> [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-8)     <div class="price">$999.99</div> [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-9)     <div class="specs"> [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-10)         <ul> [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-11)             <li>16GB RAM</li> [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-12)             <li>1TB SSD</li> [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-13)         </ul> [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-14)     </div> [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-15) </div> [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-16) """ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-17) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-18) # Option 1: Using OpenAI (requires API token) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-19) css_schema = JsonCssExtractionStrategy.generate_schema( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-20)     html, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-21)     schema_type="css",  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-22)     llm_config = LLMConfig(provider="openai/gpt-4o",api_token="your-openai-token") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-23) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-24) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-25) # Option 2: Using Ollama (open source, no token needed) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-26) xpath_schema = JsonXPathExtractionStrategy.generate_schema( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-27)     html, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-28)     schema_type="xpath", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-29)     llm_config = LLMConfig(provider="ollama/llama3.3", api_token=None)  # Not needed for Ollama [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-30) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-31) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-32) # Use the generated schema for fast, repeated extractions [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/#__codelineno-12-33) strategy = JsonCssExtractionStrategy(css_schema)`

### LLM Provider Options

1.  **OpenAI GPT-4 (`openai/gpt4o`)**
2.  Default provider
3.  Requires an API token
4.  Generally provides more accurate schemas
5.  Set via environment variable: `OPENAI_API_KEY`
    
6.  **Ollama (`ollama/llama3.3`)**
    
7.  Open source alternative
8.  No API token required
9.  Self-hosted option
10.  Good for development and testing

### Benefits of Schema Generation

1.  **One-Time Cost**: While schema generation uses LLM, it's a one-time cost. The generated schema can be reused for unlimited extractions without further LLM calls.
2.  **Smart Pattern Recognition**: The LLM analyzes the HTML structure and identifies common patterns, often producing more robust selectors than manual attempts.
3.  **Automatic Nesting**: Complex nested structures are automatically detected and properly represented in the schema.
4.  **Learning Tool**: The generated schemas serve as excellent examples for learning how to write your own schemas.

### Best Practices

1.  **Review Generated Schemas**: While the generator is smart, always review and test the generated schema before using it in production.
2.  **Provide Representative HTML**: The better your sample HTML represents the overall structure, the more accurate the generated schema will be.
3.  **Consider Both CSS and XPath**: Try both schema types and choose the one that works best for your specific case.
4.  **Cache Generated Schemas**: Since generation uses LLM, save successful schemas for reuse.
5.  **API Token Security**: Never hardcode API tokens. Use environment variables or secure configuration management.
6.  **Choose Provider Wisely**:
7.  Use OpenAI for production-quality schemas
8.  Use Ollama for development, testing, or when you need a self-hosted solution

* * *

10\. Conclusion
---------------

With Crawl4AI's LLM-free extraction strategies - `JsonCssExtractionStrategy`, `JsonXPathExtractionStrategy`, and now `RegexExtractionStrategy` - you can build powerful pipelines that:

*   Scrape any consistent site for structured data.
*   Support nested objects, repeating lists, or pattern-based extraction.
*   Scale to thousands of pages quickly and reliably.

**Choosing the Right Strategy**:

*   Use **`RegexExtractionStrategy`** for fast extraction of common data types like emails, phones, URLs, dates, etc.
*   Use **`JsonCssExtractionStrategy`** or **`JsonXPathExtractionStrategy`** for structured data with clear HTML patterns
*   If you need both: first extract structured data with JSON strategies, then use regex on specific fields

**Remember**: For repeated, structured data, you don't need to pay for or wait on an LLM. Well-crafted schemas and regex patterns get you the data faster, cleaner, and cheaper—**the real power** of Crawl4AI.

**Last Updated**: 2025-05-02

* * *

That's it for **Extracting JSON (No LLM)**! You've seen how schema-based approaches (either CSS or XPath) and regex patterns can handle everything from simple lists to deeply nested product catalogs—instantly, with minimal overhead. Enjoy building robust scrapers that produce consistent, structured JSON for your data pipelines!

* * *

# Quick Start - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Getting Started with Crawl4AI
=============================

Welcome to **Crawl4AI**, an open-source LLM-friendly Web Crawler & Scraper. In this tutorial, you’ll:

1.  Run your **first crawl** using minimal configuration.
2.  Generate **Markdown** output (and learn how it’s influenced by content filters).
3.  Experiment with a simple **CSS-based extraction** strategy.
4.  See a glimpse of **LLM-based extraction** (including open-source and closed-source model options).
5.  Crawl a **dynamic** page that loads content via JavaScript.

* * *

1\. Introduction
----------------

Crawl4AI provides:

*   An asynchronous crawler, **`AsyncWebCrawler`**.
*   Configurable browser and run settings via **`BrowserConfig`** and **`CrawlerRunConfig`**.
*   Automatic HTML-to-Markdown conversion via **`DefaultMarkdownGenerator`** (supports optional filters).
*   Multiple extraction strategies (LLM-based or “traditional” CSS/XPath-based).

By the end of this guide, you’ll have performed a basic crawl, generated Markdown, tried out two extraction strategies, and crawled a dynamic page that uses “Load More” buttons or JavaScript updates.

* * *

2\. Your First Crawl
--------------------

Here’s a minimal Python script that creates an **`AsyncWebCrawler`**, fetches a webpage, and prints the first 300 characters of its Markdown output:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-0-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-0-2) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-0-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-0-4) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-0-5)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-0-6)         result = await crawler.arun("https://example.com") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-0-7)         print(result.markdown[:300])  # Print first 300 chars [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-0-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-0-9) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-0-10)     asyncio.run(main())`

**What’s happening?** - **`AsyncWebCrawler`** launches a headless browser (Chromium by default). - It fetches `https://example.com`. - Crawl4AI automatically converts the HTML into Markdown.

You now have a simple, working crawl!

* * *

3\. Basic Configuration (Light Introduction)
--------------------------------------------

Crawl4AI’s crawler can be heavily customized using two main classes:

1. **`BrowserConfig`**: Controls browser behavior (headless or full UI, user agent, JavaScript toggles, etc.).  
2. **`CrawlerRunConfig`**: Controls how each crawl runs (caching, extraction, timeouts, hooking, etc.).

Below is an example with minimal usage:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-2) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, BrowserConfig, CrawlerRunConfig, CacheMode [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-4) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-5)     browser_conf = BrowserConfig(headless=True)  # or False to see the browser [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-6)     run_conf = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-7)         cache_mode=CacheMode.BYPASS [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-8)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-9) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-10)     async with AsyncWebCrawler(config=browser_conf) as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-11)         result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-12)             url="https://example.com", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-13)             config=run_conf [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-14)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-15)         print(result.markdown) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-16) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-17) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-1-18)     asyncio.run(main())`

> IMPORTANT: By default cache mode is set to `CacheMode.ENABLED`. So to have fresh content, you need to set it to `CacheMode.BYPASS`

We’ll explore more advanced config in later tutorials (like enabling proxies, PDF output, multi-tab sessions, etc.). For now, just note how you pass these objects to manage crawling.

* * *

4\. Generating Markdown Output
------------------------------

By default, Crawl4AI automatically generates Markdown from each crawled page. However, the exact output depends on whether you specify a **markdown generator** or **content filter**.

*   **`result.markdown`**:  
    The direct HTML-to-Markdown conversion.
*   **`result.markdown.fit_markdown`**:  
    The same content after applying any configured **content filter** (e.g., `PruningContentFilter`).

### Example: Using a Filter with `DefaultMarkdownGenerator`

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-1) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-2) from crawl4ai.content_filter_strategy import PruningContentFilter [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-3) from crawl4ai.markdown_generation_strategy import DefaultMarkdownGenerator [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-5) md_generator = DefaultMarkdownGenerator( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-6)     content_filter=PruningContentFilter(threshold=0.4, threshold_type="fixed") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-7) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-9) config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-10)     cache_mode=CacheMode.BYPASS, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-11)     markdown_generator=md_generator [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-12) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-14) async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-15)     result = await crawler.arun("https://news.ycombinator.com", config=config) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-16)     print("Raw Markdown length:", len(result.markdown.raw_markdown)) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-2-17)     print("Fit Markdown length:", len(result.markdown.fit_markdown))`

**Note**: If you do **not** specify a content filter or markdown generator, you’ll typically see only the raw Markdown. `PruningContentFilter` may adds around `50ms` in processing time. We’ll dive deeper into these strategies in a dedicated **Markdown Generation** tutorial.

* * *

5\. Simple Data Extraction (CSS-based)
--------------------------------------

Crawl4AI can also extract structured data (JSON) using CSS or XPath selectors. Below is a minimal CSS-based example:

> **New!** Crawl4AI now provides a powerful utility to automatically generate extraction schemas using LLM. This is a one-time cost that gives you a reusable schema for fast, LLM-free extractions:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-1) from crawl4ai import JsonCssExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-2) from crawl4ai import LLMConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-4) # Generate a schema (one-time cost) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-5) html = "<div class='product'><h2>Gaming Laptop</h2><span class='price'>$999.99</span></div>" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-7) # Using OpenAI (requires API token) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-8) schema = JsonCssExtractionStrategy.generate_schema( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-9)     html, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-10)     llm_config = LLMConfig(provider="openai/gpt-4o",api_token="your-openai-token")  # Required for OpenAI [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-11) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-12) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-13) # Or using Ollama (open source, no token needed) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-14) schema = JsonCssExtractionStrategy.generate_schema( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-15)     html, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-16)     llm_config = LLMConfig(provider="ollama/llama3.3", api_token=None)  # Not needed for Ollama [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-17) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-18) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-19) # Use the schema for fast, repeated extractions [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-3-20) strategy = JsonCssExtractionStrategy(schema)`

For a complete guide on schema generation and advanced usage, see [No-LLM Extraction Strategies](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/extraction/no-llm-strategies/)
.

Here's a basic extraction example:

[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-3) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig, CacheMode [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-4) from crawl4ai import JsonCssExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-5) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-6) async def main(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-7)     schema = { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-8)         "name": "Example Items", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-9)         "baseSelector": "div.item", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-10)         "fields": [ crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-20)             url="raw://" + raw_html, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-21)             config=CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-22)                 cache_mode=CacheMode.BYPASS, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-4-23) **Why is this helpful?** - Great for repetitive page structures (e.g., item listings, articles). - No AI usage or costs. - The crawler returns a JSON string you can parse or store.

> Tips: You can pass raw HTML to the crawler instead of a URL. To do so, prefix the HTML with `raw://`.

* * *

6\. Simple Data Extraction (LLM-based)
--------------------------------------

For more complex or irregular pages, a language model can parse text intelligently into a structure you define. Crawl4AI supports **open-source** or **closed-source** providers:

*   **Open-Source Models** (e.g., `ollama/llama3.3`, `no_token`)
*   **OpenAI Models** (e.g., `openai/gpt-4`, requires `api_token`)
*   Or any provider supported by the underlying library

Below is an example using **open-source** style (no token) and closed-source:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-1) import os [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-2) import json [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-3) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-4) from pydantic import BaseModel, Field [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-5) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig, LLMConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-6) from crawl4ai import LLMExtractionStrategy [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-8) class OpenAIModelFee(BaseModel): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-9)     model_name: str = Field(..., description="Name of the OpenAI model.") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-10)     input_fee: str = Field(..., description="Fee for input token for the OpenAI model.") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-11)     output_fee: str = Field( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-12)         ..., description="Fee for output token for the OpenAI model." [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-13)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-14) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-15) async def extract_structured_data_using_llm( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-16)     provider: str, api_token: str = None, extra_headers: Dict[str, str] = None [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-17) ): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-18)     print(f"\n--- Extracting Structured Data with {provider} ---") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-19) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-20)     if api_token is None and provider != "ollama": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-21)         print(f"API token is required for {provider}. Skipping this example.") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-22)         return [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-23) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-24)     browser_config = BrowserConfig(headless=True) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-25) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-26)     extra_args = {"temperature": 0, "top_p": 0.9, "max_tokens": 2000} [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-27)     if extra_headers: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-28)         extra_args["extra_headers"] = extra_headers [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-29) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-30)     crawler_config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-31)         cache_mode=CacheMode.BYPASS, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-32)         word_count_threshold=1, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-33)         page_timeout=80000, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-34)         extraction_strategy=LLMExtractionStrategy( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-35)             llm_config = LLMConfig(provider=provider,api_token=api_token), [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-36)             schema=OpenAIModelFee.model_json_schema(), [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-37)             extraction_type="schema", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-38)             instruction="""From the crawled content, extract all mentioned model names along with their fees for input and output tokens.  [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-39)             Do not miss any models in the entire content.""", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-40)             extra_args=extra_args, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-41)         ), [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-42)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-43) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-44)     async with AsyncWebCrawler(config=browser_config) as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-45)         result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-46)             url="https://openai.com/api/pricing/", config=crawler_config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-47)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-48)         print(result.extracted_content) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-49) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-50) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-51) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-52)     asyncio.run( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-53)         extract_structured_data_using_llm( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-54)             provider="openai/gpt-4o", api_token=os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-55)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-5-56)     )`

**What’s happening?** - We define a Pydantic schema (`PricingInfo`) describing the fields we want. - The LLM extraction strategy uses that schema and your instructions to transform raw text into structured JSON. - Depending on the **provider** and **api\_token**, you can use local models or a remote API.

* * *

7\. Adaptive Crawling (New!)
----------------------------

Crawl4AI now includes intelligent adaptive crawling that automatically determines when sufficient information has been gathered. Here's a quick example:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-2) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, AdaptiveCrawler [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-4) async def adaptive_example(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-5)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-6)         adaptive = AdaptiveCrawler(crawler) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-8)         # Start adaptive crawling [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-9)         result = await adaptive.digest( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-10)             start_url="https://docs.python.org/3/", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-11)             query="async context managers" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-12)         ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-14)         # View results [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-15)         adaptive.print_stats() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-16)         print(f"Crawled {len(result.crawled_urls)} pages") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-17)         print(f"Achieved {adaptive.confidence:.0%} confidence") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-18) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-19) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-6-20)     asyncio.run(adaptive_example())`

**What's special about adaptive crawling?** - **Automatic stopping**: Stops when sufficient information is gathered - **Intelligent link selection**: Follows only relevant links - **Confidence scoring**: Know how complete your information is

[Learn more about Adaptive Crawling →](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/adaptive-crawling/)

* * *

8\. Multi-URL Concurrency (Preview)
-----------------------------------

If you need to crawl multiple URLs in **parallel**, you can use `arun_many()`. By default, Crawl4AI employs a **MemoryAdaptiveDispatcher**, automatically adjusting concurrency based on system resources. Here’s a quick glimpse:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-1) import asyncio [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-2) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, CrawlerRunConfig, CacheMode [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-4) async def quick_parallel_example(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-5)     urls = [ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-6)         "https://example.com/page1", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-7)         "https://example.com/page2", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-8)         "https://example.com/page3" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-9)     ] [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-11)     run_conf = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-12)         cache_mode=CacheMode.BYPASS, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-13)         stream=True  # Enable streaming mode [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-14)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-15) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-16)     async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-17)         # Stream results as they complete [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-18)         async for result in await crawler.arun_many(urls, config=run_conf): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-19)             if result.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-20)                 print(f"[OK] {result.url}, length: {len(result.markdown.raw_markdown)}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-21)             else: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-22)                 print(f"[ERROR] {result.url} => {result.error_message}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-23) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-24)         # Or get all results at once (default behavior) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-25)         run_conf = run_conf.clone(stream=False) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-26)         results = await crawler.arun_many(urls, config=run_conf) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-27)         for res in results: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-28)             if res.success: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-29)                 print(f"[OK] {res.url}, length: {len(res.markdown.raw_markdown)}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-30)             else: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-31)                 print(f"[ERROR] {res.url} => {res.error_message}") [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-32) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-33) if __name__ == "__main__": [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/core/quickstart/#__codelineno-7-34)     asyncio.run(quick_parallel_example())`

The example above shows two ways to handle multiple URLs: 1. **Streaming mode** (`stream=True`): Process results as they become available using `async for` 2. **Batch mode** (`stream=False`): Wait for all results to complete

For more advanced concurrency (e.g., a **semaphore-based** approach, **adaptive memory usage throttling**, or customized rate limiting), see [Advanced Multi-URL Crawling](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/multi-url-crawling/)
.

**Key Points**:

*   **`BrowserConfig(headless=False)`**: We want to watch it click “Next Page.”
*   **`CrawlerRunConfig(...)`**: We specify the extraction strategy, pass `session_id` to reuse the same page.
*   **`js_code`** and **`wait_for`** are used for subsequent pages (`page > 0`) to click the “Next” button and wait for new commits to load.
*   **`js_only=True`** indicates we’re not re-navigating but continuing the existing session.
*   Finally, we call `kill_session()` to clean up the page and browser session.

# Solving the Virtual Scroll Puzzle: How Crawl4AI Captures What Others Miss - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Solving the Virtual Scroll Puzzle: How Crawl4AI Captures What Others Miss
=========================================================================

_Published on June 29, 2025 • 10 min read_

_By [unclecode](https://x.com/unclecode)
 • Follow me on [X/Twitter](https://x.com/unclecode)
 for more web scraping insights_

* * *

The Invisible Content Crisis
----------------------------

You know that feeling when you're scrolling through Twitter, and suddenly realize you can't scroll back to that brilliant tweet from an hour ago? It's not your browser being quirky—it's virtual scrolling at work. And if this frustrates you as a user, imagine being a web scraper trying to capture all those tweets.

Here's the dirty secret of modern web development: **most of the content you see doesn't actually exist**.

Let me explain. Open Twitter right now and scroll for a bit. Now inspect the DOM. You'll find maybe 20-30 tweet elements, yet you just scrolled past hundreds. Where did they go? They were never really there—just temporary ghosts passing through a revolving door of DOM elements.

This is virtual scrolling, and it's everywhere: Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, Reddit, data tables, analytics dashboards. It's brilliant for performance but catastrophic for traditional web scraping.

The Great DOM Disappearing Act
------------------------------

Let's visualize what's happening:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-0-1) Traditional Infinite Scroll:         Virtual Scroll: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-0-2) ┌─────────────┐                     ┌─────────────┐ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-0-3) │ Item 1      │                     │ Item 11     │  ← Items 1-10? Gone. [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-0-4) │ Item 2      │                     │ Item 12     │  ← Only what's visible [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-0-5) │ ...         │                     │ Item 13     │    exists in the DOM [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-0-6) │ Item 10     │                     │ Item 14     │ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-0-7) │ Item 11 NEW │                     │ Item 15     │ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-0-8) │ Item 12 NEW │                     └─────────────┘ [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-0-9) └─────────────┘                      [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-0-10) DOM: 12 items & growing             DOM: Always ~5 items`

Traditional scrapers see this and capture... 5 items. Out of thousands. It's like trying to photograph a train by taking a picture of one window.

Why Virtual Scroll Broke Everything
-----------------------------------

When I first encountered this with Crawl4AI, I thought it was a bug. My scraper would perfectly capture the initial tweets, but scrolling did... nothing. The DOM element count stayed constant. The HTML size barely changed. Yet visually, new content kept appearing.

It took me embarrassingly long to realize: **the website was gaslighting my scraper**.

Virtual scroll is deceptively simple: 1. Keep only visible items in DOM (usually 10-30 elements) 2. As user scrolls down, remove top items, add bottom items 3. As user scrolls up, remove bottom items, add top items 4. Maintain the illusion of a continuous list

For users, it's seamless. For scrapers, it's a nightmare. Traditional approaches fail because: - `document.scrollingElement.scrollHeight` lies to you - Waiting for new elements is futile—they replace, not append - Screenshots only capture the current viewport - Even browser automation tools get fooled

The Three-State Solution
------------------------

After much experimentation (and several cups of coffee), I realized we needed to think differently. Instead of fighting virtual scroll, we needed to understand it. This led to identifying three distinct scrolling behaviors:

### State 1: No Change (The Stubborn Page)

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-1-1) scroll() → same content → continue trying`

The page doesn't react to scrolling. Either we've hit the end, or it's not a scrollable container.

### State 2: Appending (The Traditional Friend)

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-2-1) scroll() → old content + new content → all good!`

Classic infinite scroll. New content appends to existing content. Our traditional tools work fine here.

### State 3: Replacing (The Trickster)

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-3-1) scroll() → completely different content → capture everything!`

Virtual scroll detected! Content is being replaced. This is where our new magic happens.

Introducing VirtualScrollConfig
-------------------------------

Here's how Crawl4AI solves this puzzle:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-1) from crawl4ai import AsyncWebCrawler, VirtualScrollConfig, CrawlerRunConfig [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-3) # Configure virtual scroll handling [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-4) virtual_config = VirtualScrollConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-5)     container_selector="#timeline",    # What to scroll [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-6)     scroll_count=30,                   # How many times [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-7)     scroll_by="container_height",      # How much each time [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-8)     wait_after_scroll=0.5             # Pause for content to load [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-9) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-11) # Use it in your crawl [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-12) config = CrawlerRunConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-13)     virtual_scroll_config=virtual_config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-14) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-15) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-16) async with AsyncWebCrawler() as crawler: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-17)     result = await crawler.arun( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-18)         url="https://twitter.com/search?q=AI", [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-19)         config=config [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-20)     ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-4-21)     # result.html now contains ALL tweets, not just visible ones!`

But here's where it gets clever...

The Magic Behind the Scenes
---------------------------

When Crawl4AI encounters a virtual scroll container, it:

1.  **Takes a snapshot** of the initial HTML
2.  **Scrolls** by the configured amount
3.  **Waits** for the DOM to update
4.  **Compares** the new HTML with the previous
5.  **Detects** which of our three states we're in
6.  **For State 3** (virtual scroll), stores the HTML chunk
7.  **Repeats** until done
8.  **Merges** all chunks intelligently

The merging is crucial. We can't just concatenate HTML—we'd get duplicates. Instead, we: - Parse each chunk into elements - Create fingerprints using normalized text - Keep only unique elements - Maintain the original order - Return clean, complete HTML

Real-World Example: Capturing Twitter Threads
---------------------------------------------

Let's see this in action with a real Twitter thread:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-5-1) async def capture_twitter_thread(): [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-5-3)     virtual_config = VirtualScrollConfig( Performance Insights
--------------------

During testing, we achieved remarkable results:

| Site | Without Virtual Scroll | With Virtual Scroll | Improvement |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Twitter Timeline | 10 tweets | 490 tweets | **49x** |
| Instagram Grid | 12 posts | 999 posts | **83x** |
| LinkedIn Feed | 5 posts | 200 posts | **40x** |
| Reddit Comments | 25 comments | 500 comments | **20x** |

The best part? It's automatic. If the page doesn't use virtual scroll, Crawl4AI handles it normally. No configuration changes needed.

When to Use Virtual Scroll
--------------------------

Use `VirtualScrollConfig` when: - ✅ Scrolling seems to "eat" previous content - ✅ DOM element count stays suspiciously constant - ✅ You're scraping Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, Reddit - ✅ Working with modern data tables or dashboards - ✅ Traditional scrolling captures only a fraction of content

Don't use it when: - ❌ Content accumulates normally (use `scan_full_page` instead) - ❌ Page has no scrollable containers - ❌ You only need the initially visible content - ❌ Working with static or traditionally paginated sites

Advanced Techniques
-------------------

### Handling Mixed Content

Some sites mix approaches—featured content stays while regular content virtualizes:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-6-1) # News site with pinned articles + virtual scroll feed [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-6-2) virtual_config = VirtualScrollConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-6-3)     container_selector=".main-feed",  # Only the feed scrolls virtually [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-6-4)     scroll_count=30, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-6-5)     scroll_by="container_height" [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-6-6) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-6-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-6-8) # Featured articles remain throughout the crawl [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-6-9) # Regular articles are captured via virtual scroll`

### Optimizing Performance

The Technical Deep Dive
-----------------------

For the curious, here's how our deduplication works:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-1) // Simplified version of our deduplication logic [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-2) function createFingerprint(element) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-3)     const text = element.innerText [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-4)         .toLowerCase() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-5)         .replace(/[\s\W]/g, '');  // Remove spaces and symbols [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-6)     return text; [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-7) } [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-8) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-9) function mergeChunks(chunks) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-10)     const seen = new Set(); [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-11)     const unique = []; [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-12) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-13)     for (const chunk of chunks) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-14)         const elements = parseHTML(chunk); [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-15)         for (const element of elements) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-16)             const fingerprint = createFingerprint(element); [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-17)             if (!seen.has(fingerprint)) { [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-18)                 seen.add(fingerprint); [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-19)                 unique.push(element); [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-20)             } [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-21)         } [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-22)     } [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-23) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-24)     return unique; [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/blog/articles/virtual-scroll-revolution/#__codelineno-9-25) }`

Simple, but effective. We normalize text to catch duplicates even with slight HTML differences.

What This Means for Web Scraping
--------------------------------

Virtual scroll support in Crawl4AI represents a paradigm shift. We're no longer limited to what's immediately visible or what traditional scrolling reveals. We can now capture the full content of virtually any modern website.

This opens new possibilities: - **Complete social media analysis**: Every tweet, every comment, every reaction - **Comprehensive data extraction**: Full tables, complete lists, entire feeds - **Historical research**: Capture entire timelines, not just recent posts - **Competitive intelligence**: See everything your competitors are showing their users

# Adaptive Strategies - Crawl4AI Documentation (v0.7.x)

Advanced Adaptive Strategies
============================

Overview
--------

While the default adaptive crawling configuration works well for most use cases, understanding the underlying strategies and scoring mechanisms allows you to fine-tune the crawler for specific domains and requirements.

The Three-Layer Scoring System
------------------------------

### 1\. Coverage Score

Coverage measures how comprehensively your knowledge base covers the query terms and related concepts.

#### Mathematical Foundation

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-0-1) Coverage(K, Q) = Σ(t ∈ Q) score(t, K) / |Q| [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-0-2) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-0-3) where score(t, K) = doc_coverage(t) × (1 + freq_boost(t))`

#### Components

*   **Document Coverage**: Percentage of documents containing the term
*   **Frequency Boost**: Logarithmic bonus for term frequency
*   **Query Decomposition**: Handles multi-word queries intelligently

#### Tuning Coverage

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-1) # For technical documentation with specific terminology [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-2) config = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-3)     confidence_threshold=0.85,  # Require high coverage [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-4)     top_k_links=5              # Cast wider net [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-5) ) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-7) # For general topics with synonyms [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-8) config = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-9)     confidence_threshold=0.6,   # Lower threshold [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-10)     top_k_links=2              # More focused [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-1-11) )`

### 2\. Consistency Score

Consistency evaluates whether the information across pages is coherent and non-contradictory.

#### How It Works

1.  Extracts key statements from each document
2.  Compares statements across documents
3.  Measures agreement vs. contradiction
4.  Returns normalized score (0-1)

#### Practical Impact

*   **High consistency (>0.8)**: Information is reliable and coherent
*   **Medium consistency (0.5-0.8)**: Some variation, but generally aligned
*   **Low consistency (<0.5)**: Conflicting information, need more sources

### 3\. Saturation Score

Saturation detects when new pages stop providing novel information.

#### Detection Algorithm

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-2-1) # Tracks new unique terms per page [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-2-2) new_terms_page_1 = 50 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-2-3) new_terms_page_2 = 30  # 60% of first [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-2-4) new_terms_page_3 = 15  # 50% of second [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-2-5) new_terms_page_4 = 5   # 33% of third [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-2-6) # Saturation detected: rapidly diminishing returns`

#### Configuration

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-3-1) config = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-3-2)     min_gain_threshold=0.1  # Stop if <10% new information [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-3-3) )`

Link Ranking Algorithm
----------------------

### Expected Information Gain

Each uncrawled link is scored based on:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-4-1) ExpectedGain(link) = Relevance × Novelty × Authority`

#### 1\. Relevance Scoring

Uses BM25 algorithm on link preview text:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-5-1) relevance = BM25(link.preview_text, query)`

Factors: - Term frequency in preview - Inverse document frequency - Preview length normalization

#### 2\. Novelty Estimation

Measures how different the link appears from already-crawled content:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-6-1) novelty = 1 - max_similarity(preview, knowledge_base)`

Prevents crawling duplicate or highly similar pages.

#### 3\. Authority Calculation

URL structure and domain analysis:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-7-1) authority = f(domain_rank, url_depth, url_structure)`

Factors: - Domain reputation - URL depth (fewer slashes = higher authority) - Clean URL structure

### Custom Link Scoring

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-1) class CustomLinkScorer: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-2)     def score(self, link: Link, query: str, state: CrawlState) -> float: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-3)         # Prioritize specific URL patterns [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-4)         if "/api/reference/" in link.href: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-5)             return 2.0  # Double the score [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-6) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-7)         # Deprioritize certain sections [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-8)         if "/archive/" in link.href: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-9)             return 0.1  # Reduce score by 90% [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-11)         # Default scoring [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-12)         return 1.0 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-14) # Use with adaptive crawler [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-15) adaptive = AdaptiveCrawler( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-16)     crawler, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-17)     config=config, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-18)     link_scorer=CustomLinkScorer() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-8-19) )`

Domain-Specific Configurations

### Technical Documentation

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-9-1) tech_doc_config = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-9-2)     confidence_threshold=0.85, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-9-3)     max_pages=30, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-9-4)     top_k_links=3, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-9-5)     min_gain_threshold=0.05  # Keep crawling for small gains [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-9-6) )`

Rationale: - High threshold ensures comprehensive coverage - Lower gain threshold captures edge cases - Moderate link following for depth

### News & Articles

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-10-1) news_config = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-10-2)     confidence_threshold=0.6, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-10-3)     max_pages=10, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-10-4)     top_k_links=5, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-10-5)     min_gain_threshold=0.15  # Stop quickly on repetition [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-10-6) )`

Rationale: - Lower threshold (articles often repeat information) - Higher gain threshold (avoid duplicate stories) - More links per page (explore different perspectives)

### E-commerce

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-11-1) ecommerce_config = AdaptiveConfig( [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-11-2)     confidence_threshold=0.7, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-11-3)     max_pages=20, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-11-4)     top_k_links=2, [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-11-5)     min_gain_threshold=0.1 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-11-6) )`

### Research & Academic

Best Practices
--------------

### 1\. Start Conservative

Begin with default settings and adjust based on results:

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-21-1) # Start with defaults [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-21-2) result = await adaptive.digest(url, query) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-21-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-21-4) # Analyze and adjust [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-21-5) if adaptive.confidence < 0.7: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-21-6)     config.max_pages += 10 [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-21-7)     config.confidence_threshold -= 0.1`

### 2\. Monitor Resource Usage

### 3\. Use Domain Knowledge

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-23-1) # For API documentation [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-23-2) if "api" in start_url: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-23-3)     config.top_k_links = 2  # APIs have clear structure [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-23-4) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-23-5) # For blogs [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-23-6) if "blog" in start_url: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-23-7)     config.min_gain_threshold = 0.2  # Avoid similar posts`

### 4\. Validate Results

`[](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-1) # Always validate the knowledge base [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-2) relevant_content = adaptive.get_relevant_content(top_k=10) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-3) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-4) # Check coverage [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-5) query_terms = set(query.lower().split()) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-6) covered_terms = set() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-7) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-8) for doc in relevant_content: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-9)     content_lower = doc['content'].lower() [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-10)     for term in query_terms: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-11)         if term in content_lower: [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-12)             covered_terms.add(term) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-13) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-14) coverage_ratio = len(covered_terms) / len(query_terms) [](https://docs.crawl4ai.com/advanced/adaptive-strategies/#__codelineno-24-15) print(f"Query term coverage: {coverage_ratio:.0%}")`
